Ottawa, December 17, 1907.

Sir—

I beg to acknowledge the receipt of your report as to the necessity for the establishment of a day school for the Indians at Lac La Ronge, and in reply to say that your remarks in this connection have been noted.

Your obedient servant,

[Signature]

Ottawa, November 27, 1908.

The Deputy Superintendent General,

Provision was made in the current year's estimates for a school-house at Malagawatch, N.S., where there are some twenty children of school age who have never had an opportunity of receiving an education, $1000 being voted for that purpose.

As no plans were prepared nothing was done and the amount will have to be revoted in next year's estimates. In order that the building may be commenced as soon as the money is available, our Architect should be instructed to prepare plans and specifications for a building to accommodate not more than 25 pupils.

This vote was made on the recommendation of Mr. Supt. Boyd, who pointed out the necessity for a school at this point and an item for the teacher's salary will also be included in this year's estimates.

[Signature]

Ottawa, March 5, 1908.

Sir:

I beg to acknowledge the receipt of your letter dated February 18th, 1908, in connection with the erection of a school for the Malagash Indian reserve, and in reply I have to inform you that plans and specifications have been prepared for this school and that blue print copy of same will be forwarded to you within a few days.

Advertisements calling for tenders for the school have been inserted in the North Sydney Herald and Sydney Daily Record.

A copy of the advertisement is herewith enclosed for your information.

You are requested to visit the locality and choose a suitable site for the school which should be at least one acre in extent, and preferably situated for water and drainage and convenient for growing flowers and vegetables.

Your obedient servant,

[Signature]

A.D. McLennan
Secretary.

A.J. Boyd, Esq.,
Indian Sup't.,
River Bourgogne,
C.B.

Dear Sir,

With regard to the schoolhouse for Metegoulak,
could you not arrange to partition off about 6 ft or
add 6 more to the building so as to give a corner in it
for the missionary when he comes there. The
center of this 6 ft. addition could be used for a
place for an altar. In one corner the
missionary could have a bench. Holding
books could be used in front of the altar to
be thrown back on occasion. If this corner
be said to interfere with Black Board there will
be plenty surface on other side. Besides a
portable Black Board or Black Board cloth
could be used. As there are no houses of
any comfort near the Reserve or on it I
hope there only to ask you to do this much for
your missionary & have it done.

Your obedient servant,
R. Macdonald, P.P.,

Ottawa, 31st April, 1908.

His Excellency
The Governor General in Council.

The undersigned begs to report that, a day school being required on the Malagawatch Indian reserve, in the county of Inverness, Nova Scotia, and the cost of the building being covered in the estimates for 1908-10, tenders were called for by the Department of Indian Affairs, receivable up to noon of the 10th April, 1908. The following is a list of tenders received:

Chappell Bros. & Co., Ltd., Sydney, C. B., for $1750.00
W. J. Kennedy, Batmore, C. B., * 1600.00
Peter McLean, Cannes, C. B., * 1355.26

The tenders are submitted herewith, as required by Sub-Section 3 of Section 56 of the Public Works Act, and the undersigned would recommend that, under the said Sub-Section, authority be given for accepting the lowest tender, namely, that of Mr. Peter McLean, for the amount of his tender as above quoted.

Superintendent General
of Indian Affairs.
Indian Agent McPherson having reported that there are about 20 Indian children of the Malagawatch reserve who should have school privileges, but who have to do without as there is no school for them to attend, Supt. Boyd was asked to report. Mr. Boyd visited the reserve and reported in favour of the establishment of the school.

$1000 was provided last year but lapsed and has been re-voted in this year's estimates. The tender proposed to be accepted amounts to $1355.86. The overplus of $335.86 will be available from the School Vote for Ontario, Quebec and the Maritime Provinces.

D.I.A., 21 Apr., '09.
The Right Honorable,

Sir Wilfrid Laurier, K.C., B., etc.

Attorney

Right Honorable Sir,

Some Indians object in this country.

Indians, State some interest in the Indians.

Have a band at Metagamoth 25 Miles distant. Your government is building a School House for them. This I believe I am. I wish to use this building on occasions as a chapel.

The Indians there are very poor and only few in numbers. If 6 ft or so were added to the building, this addition could be partitioned off in the middle by folding doors to be thrown back when access to the altar would be needed.

The idea could be walled off one corner for the missionary's bunk, the other for a confessional. Besides a well could be put on the School House. This, however, we could purchase if need be. Indeed we are prepared to undergo costs in the other matters also if costs are made an argument against it.

I am writing the Secretary. Kindly ask him to accept our request a chance for the time, but one to us worth very much.

Yours very respectfully,

[Signature]

Dear Sir,

I beg to acknowledge the receipt of your letter addressed to the Hon. Sir Wilfrid Laurier, which was transferred to this Department for action.

The Department in erecting the new school building on the Malagawatch Reserve has made use of an appropriation specially set apart for this purpose by Parliament and is unable to use these funds to assist in church work, as requested, and I therefore regret that it is not found possible to accede to your request.

Yours very truly,

Sir,

Having examined the plans and specifications in possession of Mr. Boyd, Esq., Indian Agent, River Bourgeois, N.B., prepared by the Department of Indian Affairs, Ottawa, for the erection of a frame school house on the Indian reserve, Malagamatchi, N.B., and having also made an estimate of its probable cost, I hereby offer to erect and complete the building according to the said plan and specifications, for the sum of one thousand three hundred and thirty-five dollars and twenty-six cents.

Should my tender be accepted by the Department, I shall be prepared at any time to enter into a contract for that purpose with good and sufficient security for its proper performance.

As a reference, I beg to give you the name of Geo. W. Kyte, Esq., M.P., M.M. at Ottawa.

I have the honor to be your obedient servant,

Peter McLean,
(Builder).

Ottawa 22nd June, 1908.

Sir,

With reference to official letter to you of the 1st instant informing you that the Department has decided to award you the contract for the erection of the Malagawatch Indian School, and I enclose herewith form of bond and contract for execution by you and your bondsmen, Mr Marshal Digout, and Mr Wm. S. Boyd, whose names have been reported to the Department by Mr A.J. Boyd, Indian Superintendent. The plan of the school building is being sent you by registered mail, and the specifications accompany this letter. It will be necessary for you and your sureties to execute the contract and bond before a notary public in order that all the blank spaces therein may be properly filled in and that no error in the execution thereof may occur. There is a blank space left on the face of the specifications for signature by you before a witness. You will observe that the plan has also to be signed by you and witnessed.

When completed the documents should be returned to the Department without delay.

Your obedient servant,

J. D. McLEAN

Dear Sir,

With reference to the new School House building on the Muscowatch Reserve, I regret to inform you that I visited the locality with Mr. Boyd and Mr. Maclean to choose a site. This reserve is distant 25 miles from me. I am very particular about signing for any site. I could not well work for the Workhouse, and therefore being up to specifications except by frequent visits. Mr. Boyd is willing to act as Inspector and I presume he is commissioned to do so since I have received no instructions to act. I am pleased that you chose this for it would entail a great deal of work on my part seeing the distance I have to travel.

Yours obediently,

J. MacPherson, M.M.,
Indian Agent.

Malagawatch School.

The new school-house has no outbuildings. Contractor said specifications did not provide for straps or hooks in cloakroom therefore they were not put in. Book-case should be provided for books and school material. Some provision for residence for teacher is required at this school. The nearest house where board might be obtained is about 4 miles distant and the intervening road is very bad. It would suffice to provide two rooms at the back of the present building with communication from the school-house.
With reference to the contents of your letter of the 24th inst., No. 31527/85, I have to say that Mr. McLean, contractor, offers to supply and place in position furnishings for the school house at Malagawatch as per annexed following, namely:

- Six double desks @ $5.00 each = $30.00
- Two chairs @ $3.00 each = $6.00
- Four rear seats @ $1.00 each = $4.00
- Two plain chairs @ $1.00 each = $2.00
- One table for teacher fitted with drawer and book shelf @ $9.00
- One cupboard with shelves to store supplies @ $5.00

Total = $60.00

He also offers to erect a small building for closets 8x8' ft. and 6x6' ft. porch, with exterior partition, two rooms, screened approaches, two small windows, one ventilation in centre of roof, two battery doors with false hinges, and hearths, and true dry earth floor - the roof to be shingled with clear cedar shingles and the walls with spruce shingles - for the sum of thirty five dollars ($35.00).

And

One wood shed 14x10' ft. and 7' ft. peak at back, with two battery doors complete 6x6' x 8' ft., one small window, the walls boarded horizontally and battened, the roof boarded with rough boards and shingled with clear cedar shingles, finished around the eaves and other places where required; a floor of two inch spruce or hemlock slats - the building to be set on posts of hemlock or juniper sunk four (4) ft. deep - for the sum of seventy five dollars ($75.00).

Or

One wood house 14x10' ft. and 7' ft. peak with pilot roof.
rough boarded, the roof shingled with clear cedar shingles,
the walls with spruce shingles, plain finish around
sashes and other parts where required, a floor of two
inch spruce or hemlock deals, corner boards 4x5-10 in.,
one small window, two butter doors complete. After this
the building to be set on posts of hemlock or juniper
about four (4) ft. - for the sum of ninety dollars ($90.00).

Mr. McLean has said nothing about painting
the building, but I think that both closet and house
shed, or wood house, should receive one coat sufficient
at least, as having regard to the difference in the cost
of the two buildings I should prefer the house to the shed.

In view of the difficulties and expense
of transporting materials from the nearest railway station
at Malagawatch, a distance of fifteen miles with very
rough roads, I consider Mr. McLean's offers are quite
reasonable and would recommend them a acceptance
by the Department.

Mr. McLean is not prepared at present
to give an estimate of the cost of sinking a well at
Malagawatch Reserve, but will be in a position to do so a
little later. Has the Department in mind a "driven" well,
or an excavated well with wellhead sides?

I enclose a rough blue print of plans
for a well such as Mr. McLean could supply.
Please return blueprint which belongs therein.

Big Harbor Island,
N.S., Oct. 16th. 1911.

To A.J. Boyd, Esq.,
"Indian Superintendent"
River Bourgeois, C.B.

My Dear Mr. Boyd,- Owing to the want of water, and other necessary accommodations for the Indian school and kitchen, within a reasonable distance, I am compelled to-day to move my family home at considerable expense. As for the well, I wish it could be completed in the near future, for it is a nuisance to have to haul water for about a mile distant, and even then to find the fresh water overflowed with the salt sea water. The kitchen stove, the school house stove and one of the stove pipes, are unfit for use in their present conditions. I have previously ordered these without any apparent avail, so I am compelled to move my family home until better accommodations are provided for, and it is not likely, I can come back myself to open the school before at least a couple of weeks. Mr. Murdoch McKay has again spoken to me about the banking of the school this fall, which he wishes you to give him. As Mr. McKay is a friend of mine, and very obliging, I wish you would advise him to do the banking at an early date, and to do it better than it has been; for last winter we almost froze in that building. The banking should commence with rough boarding from the ground to the flooring, and then with sufficient eelgrass, it could be thoroughly banked so as to make it comfortable in winter. But when not rough boarded, as above suggested, the cats make their way underneath the school through the eel-grass, let alone for the cold air. On my return to Malagawatch, I shall write you again after hearing from you.

Believe me,

Yours sincerely,

(Signed) Arsene Burns,
"Indian Teacher"
OFFICE OF THE INDIAN SUPERINTENDENT.

RIVER BOURGEOIS, N.S., 23rd October, 1911.

Dear Sir,

I beg to acknowledge the receipt of your letter of the 16th inst., and to say that I regret very much the inconveniences you have experienced on account of serious defects, as you say, in the utilities mentioned.

Respecting the kitchen stove, you will, no doubt, remember, when it was proposed to exchange it for another, you told me that it was then working well; that you had not understood it in the beginning, but having discovered what the trouble was you were quite satisfied with it; and that the necessity for making an exchange had been altogether obviated. Therefore, I have not given the matter any thought since, but I think no one can hold me to blame in that regard.

As to the school house stove and the stove pipe, it seems strange that there should be out of order, because they were new when the school was established two years ago and ought to be in good condition still, if properly cared for.

About the well, I cannot understand why Mr. McDonald has not carried out my instructions and endeavoured to make it a success. He has not been paid for the work he already did at the well, and he knows that I do not intend to present the Department an account for his services in that respect, until it be practically demonstrated that no water can possibly be got where we have already excavated for it.

I note what you say about banking the school house, and that work will be properly attended to in due time.

However, I must submit your grievances to the Department and ascertain its wishes relative thereto, before I can undertake

to

Arsene Burns, Esq.,
Teacher, Indian School,
Malagawatch, N.S.
deal with them; because the Malagawatch school may possibly be closed in the near future, for a time, at least; and, therefore, it would be unwise for me make any new expenditure in connection with it until I receive particular instructions from the Department.

Finally, I hope to be able to visit Malagawatch Reserve about the 10th. of November, when the different interests referred to above will have my personal attention, as the Department may desire.

Your obedient servant,

Indian Superintendent.
Sir,-

I enclose herewith the copy of a letter quite recently received from Mr. Burns, Teacher, Malagawatch school, and of my reply to it.

His statement about hauling water "a mile distant" I believe to be bosh; and I have serious doubts about the validity of the reasons he gives for absenting himself from duty.

If the stove and the stove pipe in the school room are out of order, they must be that way since Spring, because they were not used all summer. Then why did not Mr. Burns bring their condition to my attention during vacation, or before the time came for opening school on the 29th. of August, so that repairs might be made while school was regularly closed? It must have been through neglect, and he is to blame.

With regard to the kitchen stove, the Department may do as it pleases; but I would be inclined to politely advise Mr. Burns to procure a stove to suit himself at his own expense, because the one he condemns was suitable and new two years ago, and should be in good condition still, if properly cared for.

However, I shall endeavour to inquire fully into all the circumstances connected with the actual condition of school affairs at Malagawatch as soon as I can get round to it, and report the result of my investigation to the Department in due course, which will also be in line with your instructions in official letter of the 12th. inst., No.315275/1.

Your obedient servant,

Indian Superintendent.

Sir,

After much annoying delay, I feel in a position to state that a reliable supply of water has been procured for the use of the teacher's family and of the school at the Indian Reserve, Malagawatch, N.S. Water was obtained by boring at the bottom of a well dug and curbed with stones two years ago, which proved a failure. (See official letter to me dated September 27th, 1912 and subsequent correspondence).

The cost of all operations up to the present for procuring water is about $70. To provide a suitable pump and necessary fixtures will entail a further outlay of $25. But Mr. Burns, the teacher, wants the water brought into his house, and to do that would require an extra expenditure of $15, making the total cost $110. Will the Department agree to accommodate Mr. Burns as he desires?

In any case, I would recommend charging him with the responsibility of keeping the pump and its metal connections, once these are correctly installed, in proper working order. Otherwise, the Department may be called upon very often to effect repairs rendered necessary through accidents resulting from the meddlesome curiosity of children and others.

REPORT OF INSPECTOR M.J.T. MACNEIL ON THE MALAGAWATCH SCHOOL.

The teacher complains that the house is very cold and it cannot well be otherwise. There is no underpinning, the house stands over a foot above the ground on a number of "piles" and thus the wind has full play under it, besides that it necessarily twists with every storm. For the sake of comfort as well as to preserve the building, a concrete foundation should be placed under it. There is no entrance to the living rooms except through the school room; I would recommend that a door be opened into the kitchen, first enlarging the porch to the required size. There is just the necessary space. There are four knobs required for the doors and the out-buildings require some repairs.

Seeing that the building is said to be so very cold, I think it would be advisable to provide a base-burner for hard coal so that a continuous fire could be maintained during the severest part of the winter. The location of the building is very exposed.

SCHOOL FURNITURE REQUIRED:-
1 wash basin; 1 axe; 2 boxes castile soap; 6 towels;
6 drinking cups.

Sir:

I have your letter of the 30th ultimo, enclosing a voucher amounting to $20.90 for school supplies delivered on orders issued by Miss Gillis, teacher of the Malagawatch Indian Day School.

In reply I beg to say that a cheque in payment of this account is being sent. In future, however, this teacher as well as several of the other teachers in Indian schools on Cape Breton Island should be definitely instructed that they have no authority to incur such expenditures. All school material is supplied through the Government Stationery Office here upon receipt of requisitions prepared by the teacher and forwarded through the office of the local Indian Agent. Teachers should anticipate their wants in due time and prepare requisitions for the school material required, which they should forward to the Department as above stated. Any other supplies needed, or repairs required, should also be brought to the attention of the Agent, who should report same to the Department and receive authority before incurring any expenditure. It will be difficult in future to pay any accounts for school material ordered by teachers. I shall be pleased if you will inform all the teachers regarding the procedure to be adopted by them in requisitioning for supplies. Only in cases of emergency should purchases be made without the authority of the Department.

Sir:

I have your letter of the 17th instant, enclosing a list of articles required for the use of the school and teacher's residence at the Malagawatch Indian Day School.

In reply I beg to say that an order has been forwarded to the Government Stationery Office to send to the teacher's address, Alba Station, a Lithoplate blackboard, 15'x4', with the necessary chalk trough and moulding. When this arrives, please arrange to have it installed in the classroom.

Regarding the stove for the schoolroom, I beg to say that we are requesting Mr. Superintendent Boyd to arrange for the purchase and delivery of a stove of the type considered suitable to meet the requirements, and he will, no doubt, attend to this matter in due course.

You may also purchase and have delivered the following equipment, viz: - 1 broom; 2 kitchen chairs; 2 combs; 12 graniteware cups; 1 large sauce pan; 1 cheap looking glass; 1 galvanised pail; 12 bars soap; 4 yards towelling and 2 wash basins.

You may also purchase a small quantity of cocoa, sugar, Klim, biscuits and cheese to be used in giving the pupils a midday lunch. It is not intended that the pupils be supplied with a full meal at midday, but the hot drink, biscuits and cheese are to augment the lunch brought by the pupils from their homes.

No unnecessary expense should be incurred in the purchase of the articles which you are authorized to obtain, and properly certified vouchers, in duplicate, should be forwarded by you covering the expenditure incurred. Please have all purchases made and the articles delivered in order that the teacher can start the serving of the lunch when the school reopens after the Christmas holidays. Ottawa, October 8th, 1909.

Sir,

I have to acknowledge the receipt of your letter of the 30th ultimo submitting an offer from Mr. McLean, contractor for the Malagawatch School building, to supply the furnishings mentioned in the Department's letter of the 24th ultimo, and in reply I beg to say that you may order the desks, table chairs and cupboard from Mr. McLean at the price quoted, viz.-$60.50.

The Department will have to make some provision for the residence of a teacher and would like you to obtain an offer from Mr. McLean for putting up an extension in the rear of the present building, about 12 feet deep and the full width of the house. A rough sketch is enclosed showing where the extension should be carried out.

In the mean time Mr. McLean may be instructed to go on with the wood-shed and closets. Single closets should be put up at a suitable distance apart so that they can be properly separated and screened. The shed selected will be the one for which a price of $75.00 was quoted, but the Department does not consider it will be necessary to floor it and a reduction should be made in consequence, and these outbuildings should be given one coat of paint. The school should be banked.

A. J. Boyd, Esq.,
Indian Superintendent,
River Bourgeois, N.S.

Your obedient servant,

Sir,

I beg to acknowledge the receipt of your letter of the 8th inst., No. 35319, and to say, with regard to the matter referred to in the second paragraph, that Mr. McRee offers to put up, for the sum of three hundred and eighty-five dollars ($385), an extension for the residence of a teacher in the rear of the present building, of the size indicated by the rough sketch furnished by the Department; the materials to be of the same character and quantities as those used in the construction of the school house, except in the case of the interior finish.

Mr. McRee states that the season is getting too late for good work to be done with plaster finish in a place like Malapamulato, and that it would be better to use sheathing instead, which would be quite as expensive as the plaster.

This offer supposes that the extension would require to be constructed and finished so as to conform in every respect to the design of the present building. Viewing the matter in that light, and considering the time of year when delays due to unfavorable weather will be unavoidable, I believe that his tender is reasonable, and therefore recommend its acceptance.

Yours obediently,

With reference to the subject of your letter of the 15th ultimo, I have been able to secure an answer received last night from Mr. Macdonald, South-Western Ontario, regarding the purchase of the furniture required by the Department for the teachers' residence at Masawaskat.

OFFICE OF THE INDIAN SUPERINTENDENT,

RIVER BOURGEOIS, N.S., August 8th, 1910.

Sir,

I have to advise that I am in receipt of a tender from Mr. William J. McDonald, Malagawatch, N.S., the only one I have been able to obtain for sinking a well to supply water for the Indian School there.

He offers to bore for water, and to supply the necessary metal pipe for conveying it to the surface, besides a sink and a pump, for $1.25 per foot, which I consider reasonable. Any piping required to connect the school house with the well, if it should be thought necessary to make the connection, would be extra; and in the event of failure to get water by boring, he would expect to be paid 50 cents per foot at any rate.

I could get no one to make a definite offer to excavate for a well, and to wall its sides with either stones or cement. I believe such a well would prove more satisfactory in the end; and I would advise employing some reliable person by the day to provide one of that description.

The Department instructed me last Fall to invite tenders for this service, which I did, with the result that up to the present I have received only one definite offer— that mentioned above from Mr. McDonald.

Your obedient servant,

Indian Superintendent.

Sir,

Miss Florence A. Gillis, Teacher of the Indian Day School at Malagawatch Reserve, makes requisition through me for articles she requires to enable her to live in the teacher's residence connected with the school. I enclose herewith a memo., submitted by her, of the items she considers necessary for that purpose. The cost of these articles would be about $40.00.

I cannot very well see what use she may have for six cups & saucers, and for as many plates, knives, forks and spoons, as I understand that the only occupants of the residence would be herself and her sister. She has been boarding at a place one and a half from her school; but the road she must travel being very bleak and not used in winter, she can board there no longer. It is necessary for her to live near the school during the winter months in order to keep it in operation.

Her average attendance of pupils during December quarter was 15.15, which indicates that every available pupil on the reserve must have attended school regularly, and that the Indians appreciate her services.

I recommend that an expenditure of $40.00 be authorized to procure the articles enumerated in the inclosed memo., subject to such modification as I may be able to make. I do not think that Miss Gillis should expect the Department to furnish her with a comb.

A heater is required for the school room at Malagawatch Reserve. The cost would be about $20.00.

Your obedient servant,

Indian Superintendent.

The Deputy Superintendent General:

With reference to the letter from Mr W. Ross M.P., enclosing a communication from Mr Agent Macdonald of Baddeck, in regard to the proposal of the Council of Public Instruction of Nova Scotia to withdraw its contributions towards the salaries of teachers of Indian schools, I beg to say that I do not see that this Department can do anything to have the grant continued, as the Provincial Government is under no obligation to contribute towards the support of Indian schools. I may say, in fact, that this Department had no official knowledge of such grants being made and in providing for the salaries of teachers of schools in that Province, no account was taken of their salaries being so supplemented.

The salary provided for the teacher of this school is only $200.00, which is an exceedingly small amount to offer. Extract from Inspector's Report on the Middle River Indian School, December 3rd, Original on 116774-6.

General conditions in this school are not satisfactory. The attendance is poor and the discipline weak. The parents are not "interested" and the truant officer does not do his duty. There can be no progress without fairly good attendance and proper discipline. If good attendance can be secured and some discipline brought about one might look for a little progress.

Lack of interest on part of parents and failure of truant officer to do his duty are chief causes for poor attendance. Recommend rigid enforcement of "Compulsory Attendance" regulations and missionary work among parents with a view to interesting them in the cause of education. Some parents say that their children cannot attend school owing to lack of clothing. Prizes consisting of clothing, to be given on the completion of satisfactory attendance and progress at the end of each quarter, might stimulate attendance.

Jas. MacKinnon,
Inspector of Schools.

May 7th

The progress of the pupils is not as satisfactory as I would like it. I have no desire to place the cause on anyone in particular. However it is my unbiased conviction that the present incumbent is a member of the old conservative school and is not progressive and peppy enough to put progressive ideas in the minds of those committed to his charge. I would state that he is probably there too long. He is faithful and honest and does his best. I have been thinking of something that you may consider.

A female teacher is my choice. I would like to see someone there who would teach the Indian children how to sew and mend; how to take care of their homes; how to make use of waste products; how to cook and what to make use of in doing so. They are fairly intelligent and pick up things very quickly, as to their learning the routine they will learn that if they want to. However on the other hand a male teacher is necessary also to show them mechanics how to till the soil and conduct their farms. They are progressive if they have the right kind of leadership. They also could be made self-supporting with proper direction.

My idea would be to employ a married couple who would take the proposition in hand. The woman to teach in the school, and the man to carry on an experimental farm. She would teach the pupils the arts of homekeeping besides the ordinary school work and he would teach the Indians in general on the reserve the progressive methods of farming. Besides the salary paid to the teacher in school the man would have to receive a nominal salary.

Sir:

Re Teacher Middle River Day School.

In further reference to your telegram of the 1st, instant re vacancy in Middle River Indian Day School and your approval of the appointment of Michael Prosper as temporary teacher there, I beg to report that this position became vacant on account of the illness of Mrs. Jos. McDonald who notified me that she could not act and that she had decided not to accept the position.

Michael Prosper is an Indian and he has been teaching in the rural schools of Antigonish County for the past three years. From time to time, I have made inquiries about his work from the different inspectors and the report received was always satisfactory.

It has always been Michael's ambition to teach in an Indian School and on several occasions he has approached me with a view to getting a school. When I spoke to him about the Middle River School, I impressed upon him what the Department expected of him and made it plain that he was being put there only so long as his service is satisfactory. He has promised me to do his best, and I have no doubt but that his work in the class room will be all right. My only concern is that his conduct will be what it should be when he is living with other Indians. However, I think he should be given a chance. In view of the attached recommendation received from Inspector H.M. MacDonald of Antigonish, I would that his salary be the same as was paid to the former teacher, namely $65.00 per teaching month.

Dear Sirs:-

Returning from a few days holidays on August 30, your letter regarding the dismissal of Mr. Burns, the teacher of the Middle River Day School, and the appointment of Mr. Prosper was before me. Mr. Burns was still on the Reserve and had no notification of his dismissal till then; also Mr. Prosper had gone there to take his place.

The time was short before the opening of the school and tried to do business with you by wire but find that there is something wrong some place. As the agent here I am strongly opposed to the appointment of Mr. Prosper as the teacher of the school, because of his behavior on the Reserve as teacher last fall. This may be news to you but not to me and to put things through some official form I investigated the case Saturday and found that things were really worse that I knew before.

This man, Mr. Prosper has been drinking on the Reserve so much that he did not attend to his school duties, and according to the Captain used to go across the bay for a week-end spree with some of the other Indians. He also used the residence to hold boose parties, so much so, that the greater and the better class of Indians of the Reserve do not want him back. Dr. Gillis of Baddeck who attends the Indians states the same thing and tells me that Mr. Prosper's first official act on arriving was to visit the Government Vendor not once but twice before going to the Reserve. Mr. John E. Campbell, a former Agent and in touch with the Indians since the last half century, also confirms this and says that it would be folly to put Mr. Prosper in as teacher. Even Mr. Mac Rae who furnishes the supplies strongly condemns the idea of having Mr. Prosper back.

I know that it is the wish of the Dept. to try satisfy the Indians in so far as they are able. The element backing
up Mr. Prosper are very few and his associates in his debauchery. Regarding the petition headed by the so-called chief Ben Christmas of Sydney, it was prompted by the same source, a good-for-nothing Indian at this Reserve, John Julian. To show the attitude of Mr. Prosper towards authority, he did not even go to see the Captain on his arrival.

I have informed Dr. Johnson M.P. of this matter and he will put his recommendation to those statements. The school is closed at present and Mr. Burns is still on the Reserve and I would recommend that he be reinstated as teacher. As far as I know the man he does his work well and quite capable of teaching the Indians.

Awaiting your early reply and assuring you that I will have no part in the appointment of Mr. Prosper nor will I hold myself responsible for any of his actions in case he is appointed. I remain.

Yours very truly,

[Signature]

Dear Sir or Madam:

As you are aware the government is at this time making a strong and wide-spread appeal for the citizens of the country to invest their savings in War Savings Certificates in the greatest measure possible. Efforts are being made to bring this appeal before the people through every branch of industry. I have been requested personally by our Minister to place before you the desirability of a high percentage response from members of the Civil Service, and I think it opportune to acquaint you with the Minister's views as expressed in the following:

"There can be few, if any, Civil Servants, who are actually unable to invest some part of their salary for their own and the general welfare. In very many, perhaps the majority of cases, the amount that can be set aside monthly is necessarily small but no contribution will be overlooked in the present campaign."

It is becoming universally accepted throughout the country that it is essential for us all to do our part in the prosecution of the war and to utilize to the utmost any resources we may have available to further this end.

It must be left to the discretion of the individual to determine the amount he is able to contribute, but it is strongly desired that participation should be representative and general and that the greatest number possible should buy certificates. Therefore, if for any reason you cannot invest as much as you would like, you should not be deterred from making a small investment.

We are especially interested in the contributions you may make from the point of view of the success of the Department's participation as shown by the number of investors. Therefore, if you have contributed in some other way we should be pleased to know of this.

If, so far, you have felt unable to purchase War Savings Certificates, an appeal is being made to you to review your financial position once again to determine whether you can now contribute. If, on the other hand, you have already pledged yourself in this way, you are being asked whether you can find it possible to increase your effort to assist in reaching the goal set by the government of a total investment of ten million dollars a month in War Savings Certificates.

I should appreciate an early reply as it is desired to complete our returns as soon as possible. DEDUCTIONS CAN ONLY BE MADE UPON RECEIPT OF COMPLETED PLEDGE FORM.

Dear Father:

This is a report of the Night School conducted at the Middle River Indian Day School for adult Indians. Owing to an epidemic of influenza and measles on this reserve during January and until the middle of February I could not get enough to start school, so beginning the 17th of February I taught every school-day night until the last of March, for a period of two hours a night, a total of 62 hours. The department called for three nights a week, but under the circumstances I thought it would be alright to teach every night. The subjects taught were a review of elementary arithmetic for and English for the first two weeks.
The remainder of the time was devoted to agriculture and woodworking. The agricultural subjects dealt mainly with the development of farmlands on the reserve, which was brought to your and the department's attention. As far as woodworking is concerned, they have an innate aptitude for it, and therefore they know most of the work which is necessary for farmers or fishermen.

The number enrolled were 21. The average nightly attendance was 15. They all took the course right from the beginning.

Yours truly,
Roderick Wm Coody,
Teacher.

I am 51 years of age. I belong to the Middle River Indian Reserve. On Saturday, May 31st., 1941 at about 6:00 A.M. I was walking across the Middle River bridge on No.13 highway between the Indian reservation and Ryman. At about the middle of the bridge I met Maddy Cody driving his car with Alfred McDonald and Willie MacNaughton in the front seat with him. He crowded me over to the side of the bridge endangering my life. At about 8:00 A.M. I saw Cody in the car near the teachers residence on the Reserve. The car was crossways on the road and Cody was trying to start the engine. His head was on the steering-wheel. I kept going on into the house to use the telephone. In about 10 minutes Cody came in. He had both hands in his pockets and was staggering. I was standing at the phone when he came right up to me and ordered me to "Get the hell out of the house". He appeared drunk and I could smell the liquor on his breath. He was staggering and cursing in the house. I left then for Ryman to phone. The next time I saw him he was getting out of a carrie's wagon to go into the house. Johnny McDonald was with him. I was with John and Francis George.

Signed. John Marshall
I am 40 years of age. I live on the Middle River Indian reservation. I remember on Saturday, May 31st, 1961 at about approximately 4:00 P.M., I was walking from Wynona to the reserve when I met Soddy Cody, Indian School Teacher. He was walking along the road with McManus's boy. He was staggering and I think he was drunk. He was about 1 mile from his car which was in the ditch. At about 5:30 P.M., on Saturday I saw him driving his car south on the Indian Reserve. Alfred McDonald and Willie MacNaughton were in the front seat with him. At about 6:00 P.M., I saw him driving his car past Noel Charlie's house on the reserve. He was alone in the car this time and going in the direction of Middle River. At about 6:00 P.M., I saw Duncan Macarrie bringing Cody home in his wagon from the direction of Middle River. Charlie McManus was with them.

Signed,

John Ocogoo.
I am 16 years old and I live at West Middle River. I was driving to Ryanza and about ¼ of a mile from Ryanza I met Teddy Cody and Andy McLellan. They were walking in the direction of the reserve. I picked them up with the truck and the three of us went to Ryanza where I got gas for the truck. I then drove them back to the reserve. I dropped them off at the teacher's residence. When I was in Ryanza I saw Cody's car in the ditch and he told me he wanted to go up and get Alfred McDonald to pull it out with the truck. I would say that he had been drinking but was not too drunk to drive a car. I didn't see Cody after that.

Witnessed A.A. Tyson

Signed Donald Robert

P.M. Kinney
I am 72 years old. I live at West Middle River.

I was in my house at about dark on Saturday, May 31st, 1941, when Roddy Cody knocked at the door. I let him in. He said his car was in the ditch and he wanted to get a team to pull him out. He was apparently under the influence of liquor. He stuttered when he talked and he staggered a little. I could smell liquor on his breath. John McDonald and Duncan MacMuirie who were in the house took a horse and went down the road. They were unable to pull the car out and MacMuirie and I returned later, after driving him home. In my opinion he was not in a fit condition to drive a car.

REPORT ON ESKASONI CHAPEL AGENCY FOR THE MONTH OF JULY, 1944.

We have the resignations of two of our Indian Day School teachers, one at Eskasoni and one at Middle River. Mr. A. O'Rielley was released as teacher of the Middle River School and Mr. T.W. Elmourne resigned as teacher of the Eskasoni School.

The new system of the School Unit has dropped our teacher's salaries below par and our system requires a revision upward with recognition for years of services.

We have advertised for two teachers with very little results so far.

In the event that no new school will be built at Eskasoni this year, the present one will require enlarging immediately and transportation of children from the farther end of the reserve arranged.

J.A. MacLean,
Indian Agent.

QUARTERLY REPORT ENDING SEPTEMBER 30th, 1945, ON ESKASONI AGENCY

EDUCATION:

It is gratifying to know that the school situation is improved as Eskasoni reserve since my last report. A vacant building on the Western end of the reserve was fitted as a temporary school and although it is rather small, the children in that area now have the first chance they have had in three years to attend. Seating accommodations in all the schools of the Agency are not very satisfactory but when the new desks and seats requisitioned for are received, the difficulty will be overcome. Thanks to the Family Allowance regulations, attendance in all the schools is very satisfactory; Indian Day Schools in the Agency were re-opened on schedule. The teachers being as follows:

Whyocomache.- Miss Mary MacKenzie, a new teacher.
Middle River.- Miss Catherine MacDonald, the former teacher.
Sydney.- Miss Catherine Gallagher, the former teacher.
Salmon River.- Miss Hazel Bissett, the former teacher.
Eskasoni.- Miss Catherine MacNeil and Miss Margaret Maclean, new teachers.

I wish to advise that our three displaced teachers; Miss Jennie Forbes, Afton, N.S.; Mrs. Mary MacNeil of Shubenacadie, NS., and Miss Hazel Bissett of Chapel Island, N.S., could be placed as follows:

1. Miss Jennie Forbes should be, and I have secured her consent, come to Eskasoni as a lay teacher while a Sister of the teaching Order is securing her license.

2. Mrs. Mary MacNeil of Shubenacadie, whose home is not far from Middle River, is anxious to teach there if a boarding-house can be found. The teachers' residence on that reserve was unoccupied for a number of years because the teacher was a local girl and could commute daily. While empty it was given to an Indian family, to the consent of Mr. Morris, Inspector, to allow decent accommodation for a blind Indian man whose wife was tubercular, and who were currently living in a disreputable shack. There is no house available for this family, should Mrs. MacNeil displace them. I will investigate more fully upon my next visit to Nyanze.

3. Miss Hazel Bissett of Chapel Island could go to the Truro school in Mr. Rice's Agency, which I think is vacant. Although Truro is approximately 150 miles from her home, I think she would find it easier to visit her aged relatives than if she were teaching at Middle River. There is a daily bus service between Truro and Miss Bissett's home, and it would allow her at least one monthly visit home. I have written to her accordingly, and have advised Mr. Rice to accept her, as she has done very good work in Chapel Island.

I trust you will agree with me and advise all concerned accordingly.

F. B. McKinnon,
Indian Agent.

MacNeil, to teach domestic science and assist in the teaching of sewing, housekeeping and other useful subjects to the older girls. The salary allowed Mr. MacNeil will be at the rate of $65 per teaching month. You should forward this requisition for the consideration of the Department.

Rev. Sir:

In March, last, Mr. C. J. McNeil, late Inspector of Indian Agencies, Antigonish, was instructed to notify Mr. A. Burns, teacher of the Middle River Indian Day School, that his services would not be required after June 30th, last, and also that the Department had decided to reinstate Mr. Michael Prosper as teacher, to begin duties on September 1st, next. The Department has received a communication from Mr. Prosper in which he states that he has received no notification of his appointment.

I have to request that you will ascertain, at the earliest possible date, if Mr. Burns was notified that his services would not be required, and you should then communicate with Mr. Prosper, Afton, Antigonish County, and inform him that his services have been re-engaged and that he is to begin duties on the date above mentioned. The salary allowed him will be at the rate of $65 per teaching month, less 10 percent during the current fiscal year. We are informing Mr. Prosper that he is to take this matter up with you. I would request that you give him every assistance you can in his duties at this school and in encouraging a regular attendance of the Indian children. Please advise the Department if you have been able to carry out the above arrangements for Mr. Prosper to take charge of the Middle River School on the first proxime.

Your obedient servant,

Rev. Sir:

I have your letter of the 5th instant, regarding the teaching services at the Middle River Indian Day School.

In reply I have to say that, after due consideration of your report regarding the conduct of Michael Prosper, the Department cannot approve of his appointment. In this connection, I have to confirm the following telegram to you of today's date:

"Your letter fifth received. Arsene Burns re-appointed teacher Middle River School. Inform him and Michael Prosper accordingly."

You should see that this school is reopened at the earliest possible date with Mr. Burns as teacher. He will be allowed salary at the same rate as previously paid, viz., $65 per teaching month, less 10 percent during the present fiscal year.

You should see that Mr. Burns has full possession of the residence and that no one interferes with him in his duties. I would request that you give him any assistance you can in his work and in encouraging a regular attendance of the Indian children.

to be erected on the
Middle River Indian Reserve
N.S.

scale - 6 feet to an inch

June 1902
Specifications for a School House to be built on
the Indian Reserve at Middle River, Ont.

Description. A one story frame building on a stone foundation
30 ft by 22 ft, with a porch 5 ft by 10 ft. Height from
floor to ceiling 12 ft.

Foundation. Plain rubble masonry 16 in. thick at base, 6 in.
high; 1 ft. above ground and 2 ft 6 in. below. The outside
walls are to be pointed above the ground. A centre wall
to support the floor joists 2 ft high; 1 ft above ground,
and 1 ft below, is to be built down the centre of the
building. 2 in. planking to be laid along the tops of
all walls, and bedded in mortar to receive the joists.

Ventilators. Four iron ventilators are to be placed in the
outer wall; two on each side of the building.

Joists. Floor joists 2" x 10"; set at 2 feet centres.
One row of herring-bone braces to be put down through
the centre of joists on each side of the centre wall.
Ceiling joists are to be 2" x 8" set at 16 in. centres.

Flooring. To be 1½ in. dressed, tongued and grooved and
blind nailed.

Studding. 2" x 4" at 16 in. centres; double at all windows,
doors and corners.

Wall Plates. 2" x 4" double.

Walls. Outside to be of one inch rough boarding, tar
paper and drop siding. Inside lath and plaster; two
coats hard finish, except under wainscoting.

Wainscoting. To be put on the lathing after it has received
one coat of plaster. To be of double beaded sheeting 4 ft
high, well nailed to studding and lathing.

Ceiling. Lath and plaster. Two coats hard finish. A man-
hole 2 ft by 3 ft fitted with a cover, is to be placed
between the joists in the ceiling in the centre of the
building.

Roof
Roof

Rafter to be 2" X 6" at 2 ft centres; braced 1" X 8" to be well nailed on the rafters half way up. To be covered with rough boarding, tar paper and first class cedar shingles 4½" to the weather; surmounted with weather boards and roll. The eaves and cornice to be plainly finished with dressed one inch stuff.

Porch

The foundation, joists, flooring and walls are to be the same as the main building. The rafters for the roof 2" X 4" without ceiling joists; braced half way up with 1" X 8" braces; these with the ends of the rafters will form the ceiling. Ceiling to be lathed and plastered with two coats hard finish; the roof to be covered the same as the main building.

Belfry

A plain belfry is to be constructed on the roof at the front end of the building, as shown on the Plan. A hole for the bell rope is to be made through the roof, and the ceiling into the school room; both holes are to be boxed.

Chimney

To be of well burnt brick one brick thick. To commence on the top of a cupboard 7 ft high. To be neatly finished above the roof, as shown on the Plan. To be well plastered within, and the portion in the schoolroom to be plastered on the outside, the same as the walls. A pipe hole with thimble is to be placed in the schoolroom at two feet from the ceiling. To be fitted with a root box and door.

Cupboard

The sides and back of the cupboard are to be of 2" plank. It is to be fitted with shelves one foot apart, and provided with a plain battened door and lock.

Windows

To be in two cases; four lights 36-in square. Both cases to be movable and in each case, the upper sash fitted, the lower one to be weight and raised to be fitted with proper fasteners. The gable is to have the circular window (or a square window) shown on the plan, unglazed, and fitted with plain 1" X 8" slats.
Doors.

The two doors required at the porch and school-room are to be 2 in panelled doors 3 ft by 7 ft. The porch door is to have a fan light with two lights, as shown on the Plan.

Steps.

To be built to the porch, as shown on the Plan.

Platform.

The portion of the floor shown as the platform on the Plan, is to be raised 8 inches.

Blackboards.

The spaces on the rear wall between the cupboard and each side wall, are to be painted on the plaster, with prepared blackboard paint, 3 ft 6 in high, from the top of the wainscoting.

Painting.

Two coats of good linseed oil lead paint.

The outside white, with neutral tint facings. All inside wood work, light drab.

General.

A good, plain, substantial building, complete in every respect, is to be erected, of sound materials, and good workmanship. It is to be subject to the inspection and approval of the Indian Agent in charge of the Indian Reserve.

Sir:

(Middle River)

The school house, which appears to have been built upon the same plan as that at Whycocornagh, is in all respects better finished. The work done in its erection is thorough and does credit to the contractor and to the Agent who had it under supervision. The building has not, however, yet been painted outside, that the Agent informed me, not being required by the contract. The dado inside should be oiled and a bell should be provided. A coal house and separate closets are also needed. For these the Agent has, I understand, permission.

(Sgd) J. A. Macrae

J. A. R.
OTTAWA, 21st November, 1902

Sir,

The Department has been informed that the schoolhouse lately constructed on the Middle River reserve has not been painted, and I have therefore to request that you will at once call upon the contractor to have this matter attended to as the contract of Mr Norman J. Macdonald called for the completion of the building in accordance with the plan and specifications on file in your office. On page 3 of these specifications you will find, under the heading of "Painting" that it is required that two coats of good linseed oil paint be given the building, the outside white with neutral tint facings, and all inside light drab. Although the contractor was paid the Department will hold him and his sureties responsible for the completion of the work.

January 10th, 1903

To the Secretary Department of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa, Canada.

My dear Sir,

I have the honour to submit the following report:

On December 5th, 1902, I visited the schoolhouse on Indian Reserve, Victoria County. I was informed by the schoolmaster that he had recently purchased several gallons of paint for the purpose of painting the building. He also mentioned that the paint was of good quality and would last for many years.

After examining the building, I concluded that the total cost of painting would be approximately $100.00. However, due to the condition of the building, I believe that the actual cost would be closer to $150.00.

I am confident that the work will be done by a skilled painter.

Yours obediently,

J. Macdonald
Indian Agent
Victoria County, Nova Scotia
OTTAWA, 29th January, 1903

Sir,

In reply to your letter of the 10th instant giving an estimate of the probable cost of painting the new schoolhouse on the Middle River Reserve, I beg to say that the Department considers the figures quoted by you, namely from $90.00 to $100.00, too high for this work which should not cost much over half this amount. It would therefore like you to invite tenders from some of the painters in your neighborhood.

Your obedient servant,

Miss Catherine McDonald, the nurse looking after the Indian children, was at Middle River Reserve a few days ago. She thought a water container, together with drinking cups, should be placed in the school house, and strongly recommended mid-day meals for the children during winter. Ottawa, January 24th, 1925.

Sir:

Referring to that portion of your letter of the 18th instant regarding the suggestions of Miss Catherine McDonald, Travelling Nurse for the Province of Nova Scotia, when she visited the Middle River Indian Day School, I beg to say that if the teacher will undertake the work of preparing and serving the lunch, the Department will approve of the supplying of a small quantity of supplies for the purpose. This midday lunch would consist of tea or cocoa, with sugar and Klim, and biscuits or hardtack. It is not intended to serve a regular meal but only to supplement the lunch taken by the pupils from their homes. If there are facilities for making the cocoa or tea, you may purchase a quantity of cocoa or tea, sugar, Klim, soda biscuits or hardtack. A sufficient quantity of the above should be purchased to supply a lunch to the children during the present winter months or until the end of April next, only. You may also purchase a number of graniteware mugs, not exceeding 16, for the purpose of serving the cocoa or tea. If a saucepan is required in which to prepare the cocoa, you may also purchase and supply the same. It should be understood that it is not intended that any large expenditure is to be incurred, and the Department will rely on you to see that the cost is kept down to the lowest possible point.

You may also purchase a covered water container for the use of the school. It is considered that the mugs purchased for the midday lunch could be used by the pupils for drinking purposes.

Please take this matter up with the teacher at once, and if he will prepare and serve the lunch, you should arrange for the purchase of the supplies mentioned. Properly certified vouchers, in duplicate, should be forwarded covering the cost of any expenditure incurred.

It is hoped that if this lunch is supplied it will stimulate the interest and lead to a regular attendance of the Indian children.

Your obedient servant,

Dear Sir:

The winter is rapidly approaching and there are several children among the Indians who must be attended to in the matter of shoes and clothing. Although I had no direct request from any so far yet I need not wait very long. Apparently all have been getting assistance of this kind in the past. There are some who should get it, and there are who are able to provide it for themselves. These latter are sorely in need at present. Will you kindly advise me on the matter?

There is another matter I intended to take up with the Dept. Other branches of the Governments, both Federal and Provincial think it not ill-advised to spend considerable sums of money in providing prizes to encourage different activities which spell progress. On that account, I am therefore requesting the Dept. to consider the matter as regards the Indians. I would be pleased to have a check for the small sum of FIVE DOLLARS to distribute simple prizes for attendance, cleanly habits, progress in school, etc. during the Xmas season.

July 16th, 1932.

Dear Sir:

I beg to advise that Mr. Burns, teacher at Middle River reserve, Nova Scotia, was notified that his services would not be required after June 30th, 1932. Mr. Burns has written me and asks permission to remain in the teacher's residence until some time about the middle of August. He states that so far, he has been unable to secure work and just does not know where he will locate. I would recommend therefore, that he be allowed in the residence until the 20th of August. This will give a new teacher time enough to get settled until school opens in September.

You will recall that when Mr. Burns was appointed to the position last November, that the Indians were very much opposed to his coming to Nyanza. When he arrived there with his furniture, they did not allow him on the reserve. He was obliged to return to Cheticamp with his household goods and then upon my instructions, he returned to Middle River and settled in the teacher's residence. This however, necessitated his making two trips instead of one and this cost him an extra £15.00 through no fault of his own but through the fault of the Indians. Mr. Burns states that he did not and would not complain about this only that he is being dismissed now to give the job to an Indian and he feels that he should be recompensed for the extra carting of his furniture from Cheticamp to Middle River.

I may say that he has made considerable improvement around the teacher's residence and has given satisfaction and appears to be getting along well with the Indians. To me it seems only just that this voucher, in his favour, should be paid.

The Secretary,
Department of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa.

Your obedient servant,

Inspector of Indian Agencies.
Antigonish, Nova Scotia.
July 19th, 1932.

Dear Sir:

I should like to bring to your attention that the Middle River Indian day school is very much in need of cleaning. The walls of the room require to be done over with moresco or calcimine. These walls were white at one time but now they are dark and sealing, causing much dirt to fall to the floor. The approximate cost of this job would be about £35.00 and I would recommend that this work be done during the vacation, part of which could be done by some of the Indians there.

Your obedient servant,

Inspector of Indian Agencies.

The Secretary,

MEMORANDUM:

DR. MCGILL.

Middle River Indian Day School (Victoria County).
Teacher: Miss Mary E. MacLean.

There were 28 children on the roll at this school, and an average attendance of 22.

The school building is in fair shape but requires painting. There is a teacher's residence in connection with the school which also requires painting. The teacher informed me that the residence leaks badly, and I found that, to remedy this, it will be necessary to have it reshingled. I would refer the Department to the Rev. Father Rankin's letter regarding the painting of the school and teacher's residence.

The teacher gives the girls some training in sewing, knitting, etc., and from my observations while at this school I believe that Miss MacLean is doing fair work.

The yard around the teacher's residence needs draining and the coal shed should be repaired. The Chief of the Reserve was there at the time of my visit and I asked him to give Father Rankin an estimate of the cost of doing this work. Father Rankin will submit this estimate to the Department, if he has not already done so.

I authorized Father Rankin to purchase a basin, wash-stand, soap and some towels, which the teacher asked for.

M. Christian
General Superintendent of Indian Agencies.

Re: Middle River Indian Day School.

In reply to your letter of December 21st, I wish to advise that the above mentioned school should have a complete renovating job.

The shingles on the roof and walls need replacing; the interior of the building should be replastered and painted; the exterior should be painted; the floor should be sanded and varnished; a few window frames must be replaced, and doors & hardware must be supplied.

In the 1950-51 estimates an item of $1,200.00 was inserted to cover this work, and I feel all this amount will be required.

I do not think it is desirable to attempt this work before the end of the present school term.

If your office desires a more detailed breakdown immediately, I would be pleased to submit same on request, otherwise a requisition and full information will not go forward until May, 1950.

Indian Agencies.

Dear Sir,

When applying to you some weeks ago for the teaching of Students for the Post Telegraph Office in this district, I was not aware that by doing so, I was interfering in a similar telegraph office already appointed to the same work, and I shall gladly withdraw my application in his favor.

Referring to the building of a house for the teachers of Middle River Indian School, I must ask that you place the facts before the Department of Indian Affairs at your earliest convenience; the necessity for which you already are aware of, the Reserve being so far from the Village, impossible to board there, or the only available house, which I am now occupying is unfit to live in, either Summer or Winter, being extremely Cold & too far from the School.

I estimate its cost completely finished at $800. Leaving the "upstairs" unfinished, the cost would be $100 less. I am speaking now particularly of the cost of erecting such a house at Middle River. Sir,

With reference to your letter of the 9th ult., No. 116774/5, and previous communications on the same subject, I beg to submit for the Department's consideration the enclosed very imperfect sketches, of a building which I think would be suitable as a teacher's residence at Middle River.

As may be seen, it is designed to accommodate a small family, and is as limited in size as the comfortable housing of 4 or 5 people will permit, ordinary convenience and sanitation considered. In connection with such a building, I will frankly state that I should like to have one room in it set apart for my personal benefit.

With regard to Middle River Reserve, I can remain there when visiting it only until I get hungry, when I am obliged to leave and travel a couple of miles to get a meal. I should like to prolong my visit sometimes for a few days, especially in Spring; but the absence of a suitable lodging place makes this impracticable. These remarks apply also to a few other reserves.

I may say further that medical men would like to have some place where they might get a comfortable meal, and to stay over night if necessary, when visiting reserves on professional business. At present, there is no such place on any reserve in Cape Breton.

The enclosed rough sketches are for a residence 25x21 ft. of one story and an "up-stairs", or practically of one and a half story in height. The shed shaped L shown in the sketch will add comparatively little to the cost, but without it, accommodation on the main floor would be very scramp.

Between His Majesty King George the Fifth, represented by the Superintendent General of Indian Affairs of Canada (hereinafter called the Superintendent General);

And John Poilievre of the town of D'Escousse, in the county of Richmond in the Province of Nova Scotia (hereinafter called the Contractor).

The Contractor for himself, his heirs, executors, administrators and assigns, agrees to do in the most workmanlike manner all works and provide all the materials of the best kind shown in the drawings and described in the specifications marked "A" and "B" respectively and signed by the Contractor, and to complete, furnish and hand over to the Superintendent General or to some person by him appointed for that purpose, the frame building for a teacher's residence to be erected on the Middle River Indian Reserve, in the county of Victoria, in the province of Nova Scotia.

and all other work and labour incidental to and necessary for the entire completion thereof, whether specified or shown in the drawings or specifications or not, by the fifteenth day of September A.D. 1912.

AND in consideration of the above agreement on the part of the Contractor, the Superintendent General hereby agrees to pay the said Contractor the sum of one thousand four hundred and fifty dollars, provided always that the Superintendent General may at any time during the progress or after the completion or alleged completion of the work, appoint an Architect, Engineer or other officer, in which case the certificate of such Architect, Engineer or other officer, that the work is duly completed and of the amount, if any due, to the Contractor, after making such allowances for penalties and for defective or incomplete work, or for extras and deviations as the Architect, Engineer or other officer shall think fair, shall be a condition precedent to any claim by the Contractor under this contract.

AND the Contractor for himself, his executors, administrators and assigns, further covenants and agrees:

1. That the wages to be paid in the execution of this contract shall be those generally accepted as current in each trade for competent workmen in the district where the work is carried on. If this condition is violated, the Superintendent General may cancel the contract and refuse to accept any work done thereunder.

2. That if the Contractor fails at any time to pay any account for any goods or materials supplied, or money advanced by anyone to the said Contractor for the purposes of this agreement, or to pay the account of any sub-contractor for any work or materials done or supplied for the said works to be constructed under this agreement, and such
account is in either of such cases one month overdue, the Superintendent General may notify the Contractor to pay such account, and if a week elapse and the same be not paid in full, the Superintendent General may pay such account and may charge the same to the Contractor, and the Contractor covenants with the Superintendent General to repay at once any and every sum so paid.

3. That if the Contractor fails at any time in paying salaries or wages of any person employed by him upon or in respect of the said works, or any of them, and any part of such salary is one month in arrear, or if there be due to any such person one month's wages or salary, the Superintendent General may notify the Contractor to pay such salary or wages, and if two days elapse and the same be not paid in full up to date of payment, or to such other date as may be in accordance with the terms of employment of such person, then the Superintendent General may pay to such person his salary or wages from any date to any date and to any amount which may be payable, and may charge the same to the Contractor, and the Contractor covenants with the Superintendent General to repay at once any and every sum so paid.

4. That pursuant to the Statute in that behalf, this Agreement is made subject to the express condition that no member of the House of Commons of Canada shall be admitted to any share or part of this Agreement or any benefit to arise therefrom.

Ground plan for stable at Middle River Indian Reserve for use of Teacher

This building is 20 feet by 14 feet with 12 foot posts—ground floor divisions 7 feet high. Hay loft 8 feet by 14 feet 20 feet besides space under rafters. The body of the building to be boarded and battened and the roof only to be shingled. There small windows about 2 feet square as indicated on plan and three doors below and one above leading to hay loft.
Sir,

In your communication to me on Nov. 24th you asked me to give you a description of a stable and closet which I considered satisfactory for the use of the teacher on the Middle River Reserve and also to state if any person in the vicinity could do the work. I visited the Reserve on Monday the 16th inst. and found a man who can do the work and advised him to employ as his help any of the Indians who may be capable and asked him to give me an estimate of what such a building should cost. I enclose a sketch of what I consider necessary and also enclose a copy of his estimate. You will notice that I have put the closet in the barn and also the fuel room. As the weather is so cold we will have to put the building on blocks for the present and have a better foundation placed under it in the spring, which will not cost much.

The building is proposed to be 14 feet x 20 feet—without loft—to make a good hay loft. The roof only is to be shingled—the body to be battened which I think will make it sufficiently warm. The height of the loft above the lower rooms is to be about 7 feet leaving about 5 feet above for the hay space.

The estimated cost of the building as per enclosed memo is $169.67. Of course it is only an estimate and may cost more or less.

Please advise if you approve the above and if you advise me to proceed with the work.

Respectfully yours,

Sir:

A request has been received from Rev. D. J. Rankin, Indian Agent, Iona, C. B., to have the teacher's residence in connection with the Middle River Indian Day School repaired and the necessary furnishings supplied.

In this connection I enclose herewith a copy of the Department's reply to Agent Rankin. Upon receipt of the information, will you please arrange to purchase and have delivered the furnishings considered absolutely necessary. While serviceable articles should be obtained, it is not intended that any large or unnecessary expense be incurred. No doubt, the teachers themselves will provide a certain amount of the furnishings, such as linen, bedding and a small amount of dishes and cutlery.

Regarding the repairs required to make the building comfortable, I shall be pleased if you will have the work considered by you as necessary carried out. Please keep all costs as reasonable as possible, and, when the furnishings have been supplied and the repairs carried out, properly certified accounts, in duplicate, should be forwarded covering the expenditure incurred. The Department will leave in your hands the matter of having the building repaired and furnished.

Further your letter 63-1-8 dated January 3rd 1930 with reference to the teacher's residence at the Middle River Indian Day School, I beg to report that the work of repairing is about completed. In connection with this work I should like to state that the house itself which has been vacant for seventeen years has been suffering in many ways, both from the elements and from vandalism of the Indians. The outhouse, or barn, which was the rendezvous of escapading Mic-Macs, was burned a few years ago. Having no barn at their disposal the house was broken into. Several of the windows were broken and the plastered walls were damaged considerably as well as being defaced.

It was necessary to reshingle the roof which was in a very bad state of repair. It was also necessary to rebuild an outhouse or barn, which comprises a toilet, a place for fuel, as well as enough room for one cow or horse. I may add that all work done was absolutely necessary and the cost was kept as low as possible.

With exception of repairing and whitening the plaster, all work was done by the Indians under the supervision of a foreman. With reference to the amount and kind of furniture being supplied, just the mere essentials of an inexpensive kind are being furnished.

Attached herewith are vouchers for the material and labour in connection with these repairs and I trust you will find same in order for payment please.

Your obedient servant,

Inspector of Indian Agencies

DEPARTMENTAL PURCHASING AGENT

I attach account amounting to $71.33, covering supplies required for furnishing the teacher's residence at the Middle River School. TEACHER'S RESIDENCE - The teacher's residence is a good building. It has not been occupied for several years. It is, therefore, deteriorating rapidly.

Mrs. Victoria Frenzie, her son Christopher, and four children whom she is maintaining, were authorized to move into the building with the understanding that her present house would be made available to the family of Jim Peck - wife and six children. Note, Mrs. Peck is Mrs. Frenzie's daughter. The house now occupied by Jim Peck and family is to be made available to Charlie Morrison, his wife Martha, and their boy Donald, seven years old. Mrs. Morrison is an advanced TB case, and the family were living in a most disgraceful hut. It was imperative that some other living quarters be provided them. Therefore, it was necessary to make the above arrangements. The agent was instructed to have the Morrison shack destroyed by burning it, when the family moved out, as it was a menace to the health of the community. Dr. C. L. MacMillan agreed that the building should be destroyed.

On my first visit to this reserve, about half-past eight at night, it was raining very heavily and the water was coming through the Morrison shack in many places. Charlie was trying to keep the fires going. Martha was in the only bed, coughing and experiencing, with Donald sleeping with her. I came to the conclusion that the only solution was to have Donald admitted to the residential school at Shubenacadie. We intended to take him with us as we were travelling there in the agent's car. However, two days after, when we returned to pick him up the mother and father raised such a disturbance that it was decided to give them a month's extension with the following understanding, which was signed by both parents:

Donald is to attend school regularly every day. He is to sleep in a room separate from his mother. A bed belonging to the school residence, and not being used, was provided for this purpose. No doubt the boy will eventually have to be sent to the residential school. I did not wish to force the issue during the time of my visit as the parents were very upset and in a very nervous condition which might have resulted in both, or either of them, doing something desperate.
