[4.] Lighting, Ventilation and Warming. (a) The windows should be principally on the left of the pupils. There may be two behind them, but none in front of them or on the right. The front and right can be utilized for an unbroken blackboard, which should reach to within two and a half feet of the floor, and have a width of five feet, the upper portion being useful for the more permanent illustrations.

(b) The lower window sill should be at least four feet from the floor, and the top of the window as near the ceiling as possible. The left wall above the four foot line should be about one-half glass.

(c) The upper part of each window should be a transom, hinged below, or the upper sash should be hung on pulleys, as well as the lower, for ventilation purposes.

(d) The size of a school room is determined by the greatest number of pupils it is intended to hold, 200 cubic feet of air being required for each. When the room is full of pupils this air should be entirely changed at least two or three times every hour. In some of the more expensively ventilated school buildings in the province, the air is warmed and changed every ten minutes.

(e) In rural sections where economy has to be carefully considered, a large stove surrounded by a sheet metal jacket closely fitted to the floor and around the door, separated from the rest of the stove by an air space, and rising up over three feet and nearly to the top of the stove, makes an excellent ventilating and warming furnace. Underneath the stove and shut off from the school room by the jacket should be a large opening for the admission of pure, fresh air through a large tin pipe or air-tight wooden funnel running underneath the floor and through the foundation, then turning up and terminating at least six or eight feet above the ground on the side of the house, the entrance to the funnel being lateral and covered with a grating to prevent the throwing of anything into it. The stove should be two or three times larger than one necessary to warm the room without such an
[2.] School Grounds. (a) In rural sections the grounds should contain, when convenient, one acre, never less than half an acre; in thickly peopled localities, or villages, a half an acre or more but never less than one-third; and in towns never less than one-quarter, if possible.

(b) The form should be, perhaps, more than twice as long as broad, in order to furnish proper separate play grounds for the boys and girls. (c) It should be properly levelled, drained when necessary, neatly fenced around, ornamented with desirable shade trees, which should neither interfere with the play grounds nor the light of the school room.

(d) Clean water, free from the suspicion of taint from surface drainage or other impurities, should be within easy reach of the school house.

[3.] School Houses. (a) For a rural section not likely to have more than 30 pupils for twenty years to come, the school house should have the following inside measurements:

Width 23 feet, length 31 feet, (hall 6 feet, teacher's platform 5 feet, clear space 4 feet, seats and desks 13 feet, clear space 3 feet), and 11 to 12 feet high.

(b) For a section with 42 pupils: Width 24 feet, length 36 feet, (hall 6 feet, platform 5 feet, space 4 feet, seats and desks 18 feet, space 3 feet), and height 12 to 13 feet.

(c) For a section with 54 pupils: Width 25 feet, length 41 feet, (hall 6 feet, platform 5 feet, space 4 feet, seats and desks 23 feet, space 3 feet), and height 13 to 14 feet.

(d) For a section with a greater number of pupils, there should be, as required by the statute, a separate class room, large enough to be converted into a primary department of a graded school should the attendance increase.

(e) When a building is situated with its length north and south, the entrance doors can be at the south end, the teacher's platform next the entrance hall, the stove at the north end, so that on cold, windy days the heated air may drift through the whole room; the light coming principally from the east will obviate the glare of a midday sun, and the maps can be hung on the north wall to secure their proper orientation in the minds of the pupils (a very important matter), the west wall being used temporarily for maps when the convenience of teaching requires it.

The humble petition of the undersigned showeth,

That the education of the Indians on the reservation which is situated about three miles from the town of Truro is not conducted and heretofore has not been conducted according to the school laws of the province, in such cases made and provided.

These Indians are of the Mic Mac tribe all Catholics, and good citizens who are anxious to bring up their children in the faith of their fathers but under their present unfortunate circumstances they find it very difficult to do so.

Your petitioners would further show that when the Government established a school on the reservation a young man, a Catholic, holding a high grade of license, and a normal school diploma, sent in his application for the position but Mr. Smith did not forward it to the Indian Commissioner, he simply forwarded the application of his own daughter, which was the only one which reached the Commissioner, and by this dishonest conduct he secured the position of teacher for his daughter. I doubt not that Miss Smith may be a competent teacher in the general acceptation of the term, but she has openly set the School Act, of this province at defiance, by persistently teaching her own ideas of religion in the school, singing hymns and giving other religious lessons and instructions according to the ritual of the Presbyterian Church, and this she does in the face that every pupil under her care is Catholic, and against the wishes of the parents, who have continuously protested against such high-handed imposition, and the result is that many of the pupils did not attend school last year, and are being cheated out of their education in consequence of the bigotry of the teacher and the Indian Agent.

Ottawa. Sir,

The Honorable

Petition of the undersigned.

Showeth,

That the Education of the Indians on the Reservation, which is situated about three miles from this place, has not been conducted according to the School Laws of Nova Scotia, nor in keeping with the welfare of the pupils. There are some twenty families on the Reservation. The Agent Mr. Thomas Smith is a Presbyterian and does not seem to have anything in common with the Indians or their children, and instead of discharging his duty as guardian of their spiritual and temporal welfare, as the Government intends he should, he has permitted a protestant woman to go openly to their houses on Sundays during last summer for the purpose of proselytizing and robbing them of their faith. He seldom deals out even handed justice and often favors those who are the least deserving while he pays but little attention to the more deserving ones because they cannot favor his ideas. These Indians are Micmacs Catholics who are anxious to bring up their children in the faith of their fathers, but with a bigoted agent, and a protestant teacher they over which neither the parents nor their clergy have any influence, they find it very difficult to do so.

Your petitioners would further respectfully show that a Catholic young man holding a high Grade Licence Normal School Diploma sent in an application for the position of teacher last year, but Mr. Smith did not forward it to the Indian Commissioner—he withheld it—and only sent his own daughter, which was the only one that reached the Commissioner, and by such
Acting he managed to secure the position for her.

I doubt not that Miss Smith may be a competent teacher in the general acceptation of the term, though not acceptable to the Indians, as she kept up a system of religious training by singing hymns and giving other lessons and instruction keeping with the ritual of the Presbyterian Church, and thus she has done in a school where every pupil is Catholic, and against the well understood wishes of the parents who have continuously protested against such imposition, and the result is that many of pupils did not attend school during the past year, and are being cheated out of an education as a consequence of the bigotry of the teacher.

Your petitioner would further respectfully show, that in many cases the priests have been appointed agents, and such appointments generally give satisfaction.

It is the priest who gives his time and money to promote the spiritual and temporal welfare of the Indians, and while the Agent and the Doctor are paid for their work, the priest gets nothing for his services, though his frequent visits are often attended with hardship in stormy weather and always with cost, paying for living teams and other incidental expenses.

I have endeavored to lay this case before without prejudice to the agent, or the teacher, and have stated the facts of the case without any coloring.

In conclusion I would most respectfully suggest that, in the interests of justice, you should dismiss the present agent Miss Smith, because he has proved himself incompetent to occupy the position any longer — and while I do not covet the position myself for any pecuniary interest, I may feel in the matter, but in the interests of the Indians and their families, if you should think proper to give me the appointment of Indian agent for the Times Reservation, I will undertake to discharge to the best of my ability the duties
That may devolve upon me.

Meanwhile I have the honor to remain

Sir most respectfully

Yours

M. K. Kinnele

Dear Mr. Smart,

I have investigated the complaints made by the Rev. M. K. Kinsella of Truro, against our agent Mr. T. B. Smith who has charge of the Indians of Colchester Co.

The complaints briefly stated are as follows:

1. That he permitted a woman to go openly to the houses on Sundays at intervals during the past summer for the purpose of proselytizing and robbing them of their faith.

2. That he seldom deals out even handed justice and often favors those who are the least deserving, while he pays but little attention to the more deserving because they cannot conscientiously favor his ideas.

3. That at the close of the school year in July 1900, a Catholic young man holding a high grade license, and a Normal School diploma, sent in an application for the position of teacher to the Indians, but that Mr. Smith with held it and sent his own daughter's application which was the only one that reached the Department.

4. Father Kinsella asks that as the agent has proved himself incompetent to occupy the position he be discharged and the same given to Father Kinsella.
In answer to the first complaint the agent explains that a Mrs. Gunn a Baptist lady of Belmont, about two stations from Truro, came to the Reserve last September and desired to speak with the Indians in the school house regarding their spiritual welfare. The agent refused as the building was Government property, and he did not wish to have anything like that conducted in the school. On Mrs. Gunn's own motion she visited one or two of the Indian families. The agent advised them not to interfere with her, as some of them threatened to do her bodily harm. Mr. Smith told them that if they did not wish to listen to her they should go away. The consequence was that the following Sunday she could find no Indians and accordingly she left the Reserve.

As to complaint No. 2. I may say that I found the agent popular with the Indians. He is a substantial farmer and dairyman. The mere pittance of Fifty Dollars which he receives as salary from the Department is nothing to him. He apparently gives a great deal more than his salary back in the way of help to the Indians as they are constantly coming to him for relief. Mr. Smith was appointed by order of His Excellency in Council on the 21st of May, 1897 and he receives the full indorsement of the friends of the Government in Truro.

As to complain No. 3. Mr. Smith explains that the application of Mr. Hanway referred to by Father Kinsella, which is attached herewith, was received by him after the application of his daughter for the position had been sent to the Department.
and accepted. He advised the applicant therefore that the position had already been filled.

As regards No. 4. I explained to Father Kinsella that I thought the Department would meet his views as to a Catholic teacher, provided, that his nominee received the indorsement of the President of the Liberal Association in Truro; as properly the patronage of such appointments belongs to the Government. I told him however, that as Mr. Smith, the agent, was a recent appointment and had the indorsement of friends of the Government in Truro I did not think it was likely that he would be disturbed in his position. Father Kinsella however, urged that as the Indians were all Roman Catholics it was only fair that the agent should be of the same faith; that he had to visit the Reserve and look after the spiritual welfare of the Indians at his own charges, while the Doctor and the agent were salaried officials of the Government and their expenses paid.

As regards the Father's complaint against the teacher Miss Smith, teaching religion in the school, singing hymns etc., in keeping with the ritual of the Presbyterian Church, I may say that I visited mostly all the Indians on the Reserve and questioned them as to whether or not Miss Smith taught religion in the school. They all said "No", and appeared to be satisfied with the way she brought their children along. The number of children on the roll during the present year was 31 with an average attendance of fifteen. Miss Smith holds a "B" certificate from the Truro Academy and a "C" license from the Provincial
Government which equals a second-class certificate. She taught the school for two years and nine months, her salary having been at the rate of Two Hundred and Fifty Dollars ($250.00) per year.

As to the hymns stated to have been sung in the school, Miss Smith explains that one of the Indian children brought a Moody & Sankey Hymn book and she sang out of that book hymns Nos. 17, 33, and 99. She claims that no religion of any particular faith was taught by her; that she simply complied with the course of studies prescribed by the Department and only read the Lord's Prayer with the pupils every morning.

Father Kinsella visited the school about a year ago and asked her if she had a Bible in the School and if she taught religion. She told him that she only read the Lord's Prayer, and after his visit changed the form of it to suit the Roman Catholics, which was by changing the word "which" to "who" in the first part, and leaving out "for thine is the Kingdom, the Power and the glory forever" in the latter part.

I thought it necessary to make this report to you at once so that a teacher could be appointed in Miss Smith's place as soon as possible. I have asked the President of the Liberal Association to submit the name of a Catholic teacher to you and I have no doubt that this will be done in due course.

There is one thing that Father Kinsella suggested to me, and that is, that he thought it would be advisable if the Band had a duly elected Chief, there being no recognized chief at present. If you approve will you kindly give instructions
so that the agent may be advised to hold an election at an early date. I think myself it would be better if the Band had a recognized Chief.

Your obedient Servant,

Memorandum: Mr. McLean,

I have read over your report with regard to the charges made by the Reverend T. C. Kinsella, of Truro, against Mr. Agent Smith, and from what you say there appears to be nothing in them at all as the agent seems to have been doing his duty quite satisfactorily.

I do not know any reason for the change in the school teacher, unless it is that the children are Roman Catholics, but I did not understand that it was a religious school at all. However, if there is any point at all in this connection I presume it might be just as well to appoint a Roman Catholic teacher. I do not think, however, that it would be wise to appoint a Chief. It seems to me that that would be a retrograde action. What real advantage a recognized Chief is to a Band of Indians is more than I can understand in this age of civilization. It seems to me that the appointment of a Chief has the effect of making the Indians less self-reliant.

Deputy Supt. General.

To the Acting Deputy Superintendent General.

Regarding the request made by Miss Jessie M. Scott, teacher of the Millbrook Indian Day School, to the Honourable the Minister of Public Works to ascertain whether she would be entitled to a pension after twenty years continuous service as teacher in the above school, I beg to say that there is no provision for the granting of superannuations or pensions to teachers of Indian schools. A gratuity on retirement has, however, been granted in the cases of several teachers in the past. In two of these cases the teachers have taught for thirty years and they were allowed a gratuity equal to one-half of their yearly salary as at the date of their retirement. In several other cases where the teachers had not been in our service for so long the period being less than twenty years, a gratuity on retirement equal to one-quarter of the yearly salary was allowed.

I would suggest that, if approved by you, that she be granted a gratuity equal to one-half her yearly salary, viz., the sum of $250.00. This could be paid from the appropriation for Indian Education, the same as was done in all the above named cases.

Mr. Scott:

I wish to draw your attention to a matter arising out of the resignation of Miss Jessie K. Scott, Teacher of the Millbrook Indian Day School in Nova Scotia. This teacher has given over twenty years' successful service at this point and is resigning because of ill health.

A year ago Miss Scott wrote to the Secretary of the Civil Service Commission in connection with pension, and this communication was forwarded to this Department by Mr. Foran. She was informed by official letter of November 16, 1920, that there was no provision made for pension or retiring allowance to teachers in Indian schools.

Last August Miss Scott petitioned the Minister of Public Works, to ascertain whether she would be entitled to a pension after twenty years' continual service as Teacher in an Indian day school. Mr. Sutherland, of the School Branch, prepared a memorandum to the Acting Deputy at this time and recommended a gratuity equal to one-half year's salary, or the sum of $250. This recommendation was turned down by the acting Deputy and Miss Scott was informed that she did not come under the Civil Service regulations and that no annuity or gratuity could be granted.

I have taken the trouble, Sir, to look carefully into this matter of gratuity to retiring Indian day school teachers. I have learned that the Department has granted to four teachers, who have taught for periods of 17, 8, 13 and 8 years respectively, gratuities equal to one-quarter of their annual stipend, or more.

I would recommend, in view of the faithful services given by Miss Scott, and in view of the fact that her health is not good, that the Department allow her a gratuity on her retirement at the end of this calendar year equal to one-half of her yearly salary ($250). This could be paid from the Appropriation for Indian Education, as was done in all the above-mentioned cases.

Sir:

I have your letter of the first instant, enclosing the June quarter return of the Millbrook Indian Day School. The teacher's remarks regarding attendance have been noted. I would point out that, where relief is granted to Indian parents, it is expected they will see that their children of school age and in good health attend school regularly. Relief is supplied in many cases on that understanding; and, where the parties thus assisted fail to send their children to school, the question of discontinuing the relief supplies should receive your consideration and a report regarding each case furnished the Department. We understand that Mr. W. T. Gloade is truant officer for this reserve. He should obtain from the teacher, at least once each week, a list of the absentee pupils. He should then visit their homes and, if possible, conduct the children to school. For your information regarding the enforcing of attendance, I would refer you to Section 10 of the Indian Act, with special reference to Subsections 2 and 3 of Section 10.

I would recommend that Miss Smith be re-engaged for the ensuing year as teacher at Millbrook School. Regarding an increase of salary, it would seem that she is now getting more than she would get in a similar school under provincial management, but with her grade of license she could get a graded school and so much or more than she is getting now. It is a well known fact that school teachers in Nova Scotia are very poorly paid and an effort is now being made to remedy this condition and the Dept would be setting a good example if they increased the salaries of their Indian School Teachers where length of service and efficiency warranted. I feel that the Dept is spending a lot of money on Indian education and not getting very satisfactory results therefrom. In the first place the attendance is not what it should be, this is not the fault of the present officer but rather...
of the parents, they do not think it is necessary that their children do more than learn to read and write, and they make excuses that they cannot provide the smaller ones with foot wear or other clothing fit to attend school in and as they get older they are kept home to assist in work.

It does seem that when the Dept bears the whole expense of running a school that the Indians should cooperate so far as to see that every child of school age is kept going regularly.

MEMORANDUM:

The Honourable the Superintendent General,-

I have Mr. Jackson's memorandum of the 16th instant, regarding a change in teaching services at the Millbrook Indian Day School, near Truro, N.S.

In this connection I have to say that a letter was received today from Mr. B.B. Fox, the Indian Agent at Truro, in which he reports that the present teacher, Mrs. E. Smith, is a married woman, with quite comfortable circumstances. Her husband is in good health, working every day at a high salary, as foreman of one of the departments in Stanfield's Limited.

I wish to direct attention to Section 36 (1) of the Civil Service Regulations, which provides as follows:-

1. "Hereafter, no married woman, whose husband is living, shall be eligible for appointment in the public service;

2. "Provided that, when the supply of experienced help for any particular kind of work is not sufficient to meet the demands of the public service, a married woman may be certified for temporary employment;

3. "Where it can be established by a married woman that her husband is unable, through illness - or other
or other cause, to contribute to her support, such married woman may be certified for permanent or temporary appointment."

As Mrs. Smith's husband is well able to support her, I beg to recommend that she be notified that her services will not be required after the end of the present school year, viz.: the 30th instant.

Regarding the application attached to your memorandum above referred to, from Mr. F. B. McKinnon, of Truro, for the position, to succeed Mrs. Smith, I would say that he has the necessary qualifications and his appointment would be satisfactory. The local Indian Agent states that Mr. McKinnon is highly recommended by the Faculty of the Normal College and some of the R. C. Clergy in Truro. The Agent states, further, that he discussed the matter of Mr. McKinnon's appointment with Dr. Thomas Robertson, Commissioner investigating Indian conditions in the Maritime Provinces.

The appointment of a new teacher does not come under the Civil Service Commission. The salary rating at this school is $66 per teaching month. The local Agent has requested, should Mr. McKinnon receive the appointment, that the rating be increased. The Department can increase the salaries of teachers, without reference to the Treasury Board or the Civil Service Commission, and I would recommend, in the event of the appointment of a new teacher, that the salary rate be $75 per teaching month - this being equal to the average salary paid to teachers in the province of Nova Scotia.

Deputy Superintendent General.

Sir:

In reply to yours of July 7th, in reference to a communication you received from the Secretary, The Board of School Commissioners, Truro, I beg to say that at present on the Millbrook Reservation there are twenty-four children of school age. Our School now has accommodation for twenty-eight pupils and there is room in the present building for six more desks or twelve more pupils.

In conversation with the Chairman of the Truro School Board, I learn that there may be ten children from the section of Truro next our Reserve that would attend the Indian School. He suggested that a charge per pupil might be made by the Department of Indian Affairs to the Town. In our talk I suggested to him that should an arrangement be made where the Indian School would take care of a number of the white children that we have the privilege of sending some of the boys to manual training and some girls to Domestic Science classes in the town schools. He believed this could be satisfactorily arranged.

We mutually suggested that if an arrangement was made that the course of study would be the same as in all public schools in Nova Scotia and that therefore it would come under the inspection of the district School Inspector and result in the teacher receiving the Provincial grant which goes to all teachers in this Province.

Truro is facing a problem of either coming to some agreement with the Department of Indian Affairs respecting the School or erecting a building of their own to accommodate a comparative few children that are near our Reserve. It was pointed out by the Chairman of the Board that if Truro had the privilege of sending these children to the Indian School the commissioners could then put it up to the parents that they would have to send their children to our school or else to the Willow Street School two and a half miles distant.
Practically all the Indian families on our Reserve believe that a number of white children going to the school would have an influence that might get the Indian away from the idea that he must always be an Indian, never to rise above the status of a Government ward. Of course, there are some objectors both among the Indians and the whites, but they are of a small percentage.

Personally I feel that the Indian Children should be taught in accordance with the policy of the public schools of the Province so that should they advance sufficiently they would be able to continue their studies in the Provincial Normal or other higher educational institutions. Or if the suggested agreement succeeds to the County Academy.

I do not believe there need be any financial outlay except for desks to make our school suitable to accommodate the surplus that is now a difficult problem for the Truro School Commission.

Your obedient servant,

B. H. Fox,
Indian Agent,
Truro, N. S.

Dear Sir:

The Department would be prepared to grant the admission of the white children, on the following conditions:-

1. Payment of tuition fees to the amount of $12.00 per capita per annum on the average attendance - these fees to be paid at the end of each school year - the teacher of the school to keep accurate record of attendance of each white child.

2. If the Board of School Commissioners, Truro, will permit those Indian boys and girls on the Millbrook reserve who are qualified to take the course to attend the manual training and domestic science classes, respectively, in the Truro School nearest the reserve, without payment of tuition fees, the Department will agree that no tuition fees be charged for the white children attending the Millbrook Indian School. Should, however, the Board not agree to permit the Indian children to attend manual training and domestic science classes

Dear Sir;

I am writing you in the interests of the Indians of the nearby Millbrook Reserve. I am very anxious to secure information and guidance.

The members of this Reserve in 1946 formed a Home and School Association, which is a nation wide organization with membership made up of influential and interested men and women in the fields of Education, Health, Community betterment, etc., etc.

The capacity in which I write you is that of President of a Council of 20 such Associations. We are very desirous of giving some help and securing some help for these people in Millbrook. They are very anxious to help themselves and have shown this fact in forming an association whereby they may study their problems.

I have visited with them on three occasions and have had my eyes opened to say the least. Their school is in a sad state of disrepair and very detrimental to the health of the scholars and teachers. I know whereof I speak for I am a Supervising Principal of a nearby School System and have as well served my time in Rural one room schools and I have never seen conditions quite as bad—definitely. Every school in our County area are so far superior that it is pitiful.

They tell me the Indian agent has visited the School once this year and is fully aware of conditions but has not come back and he is only a few miles away. The basement is flooded so that fires cannot be kindled at times, casement windows are out, door knobs gone, sanitary facilities absent, teacher buying needed supplies out of his own money.

How do we go about having these things remedied? I am very anxious to help these people, how can I do it. Just what is the responsibility of the Indian Affairs Branch and the Indian Agent. If at all possible I would appreciate having an answer in time for a meeting on March 24th when I have promised to make a report on how conditions may be bettered.

Yours very truly,

Ralph M. Guy, Pres. County Council of Home and School

Ottawa, March 31, 1947.

Dear Mr. Guy:

Your letter of March 18th, addressed to the Minister of this department, has been passed on to me for consideration and reply.

In this connection, I am sending forward for your information a copy of a report dated August 23, 1941, submitted to the Director of this branch by W. S. Arnell, Inspector of Indian Agencies, immediately following an investigation undertaken by him of conditions on Indian reserves in the provinces of Nova Scotia and P.E.I.

What we are aiming at at the present time is the centralization of the Indian population of Nova Scotia on two reserves - Eskasoni and Shubenacadie. It is just possible that there are at a number of reserves in the province Indians who, for the time being at least, are gainfully employed, and it is our intention that these Indians should not be disturbed. On the other hand, it is difficult to justify capital expenditures on our reserves that may be abandoned in the years immediately ahead of us. It would, I feel sure, be of value to you and of interest to the members of your Association if you could find an opportunity to visit the reserves where our new policy is now in force. In addition to this, it is my intention to pass on your letter with a copy of my reply to Mr. J. E. Morris, Acting Inspector of Indian Agencies for the Province of Quebec and the Maritime Provinces. Mr. Morris will, I feel sure, be glad to discuss the matter with you at the time of his next visit to Truro.

Yours sincerely,

Dear Sir,

I received your letter dated Aug. 13th stating there will be no vacancy on the staff at Eskasoni due to Mother Zenobial being in a position to nominate a full staff of Sisters, which is perfectly all right as I understand they have charge of school - what I did not understand was how a teacher could be appointed to or for one school as Miss Forbes was appointed for Nyangwa School and then within two weeks be appointed to fill in at Eskasoni as Mrs. Macdonald advised me in a letter written July 15th and which I still do not understand or consider "Fair Play" and far from professional or Departmental ruling - no sense of justice.

In the same letter she advised me I could have Nyangwa School which was now vacant due to Miss
Forbes accepting position at Eskasoni or if I was interested in Truro school which would be convenient to reach from my home to contact H.C. Rice, Indian Agent hence I replied to Mr. MacKinnon thanking him for advising me thus and asked for recommendation which I received enclosed in letter dated July 24th accordingly submitted application and recommendation to Mr. H.C. Rice for Truro School provided Mrs. MacNeil was not teaching which would make my application uncalled for. I never received a reply up to date which must be three weeks since I wrote. Mr. MacKinnon has certainly mis-informed you re Truro School which I would have accepted gladly as I could go and come by bus and overcome my difficulty regarding my aged mother.

I am writing Mr. MacKinnon to ask him to explain the statement or information he wrote Department which is absolutely false. I always considered him fair upright and frank but your letter has completely changed my opinion.

In view of above I must ad-
mit I am baffled and confounded.

Mr. MacKinnon, Indian Agent, wrote—Sisters—one licensed teacher required—Miss Forbes asked to take position—accepts. Nyanga Indians vacant offers same to me but I do not accept for personal reason which I explained.

Then he writes—I may have a chance of Truro School, which I made application for but received no reply.

Now, letter from Department states Sisters have filled staff at Eskasoni—a contradiction of this letter, also that Mr. MacKinnon advised you I had refused Nyanga and Truro School. I did not refuse Truro School as stated before—I never received a reply from Mr. H. C. Price, Indian Agent.

Why all this deception? I am keeping all these letters but will supply any copy if requested.

I request of you an explanation even though it means an investigation promptly as possible, as I could have had suitable schools had I not waited so long for a reply or replies from Department and Mr. H. C. Price, Indian Agent respectively.

Yours truly,

Hazel Bissett.

Ottawa, July 15th, 1925.

Sir:

I have your letter of the 3rd instant, informing the Department of the resignation of Miss Alma Sheridan as teacher of the Millbrook Indian Day School and recommending the appointment of Mrs. Elizabeth Smith, who formerly taught this school, to succeed Miss Sheridan for the next school year. In reply I beg to say that the resignation of Miss Sheridan is accepted.

We note that Mrs. Smith is a married woman with a family, and that she resides near the Reserve. If you are satisfied that she will be able to give full service during the next school year, you may inform her that her appointment is approved. It is expected that she will be in a position to conduct school each day it should be in operation. She is to begin duties on or about September 1st, next. The salary allowed her will be at the rate of $65 per month for the ten teaching months in the year. I shall be pleased if you will inform the Department whether, in view of the above requirements, you have given her the appointment, and, if so, if she has accepted same.

Your obedient servant,

A. F. MacKenzie,
Acting Aest. Deputy and Secretary.

R. H. Kennedy, M.O.,
Indian Agent,
Hilden, W.S.
Ottawa, July 28th, 1925.

Sir:

I have your letter of the 25th instant, informing the Department that Mrs. Elizabeth Smith has accepted the position as teacher of the Millbrook Indian Day School for the next school year. The Department is pleased to approve of her appointment.

With reference to her request that she make monthly returns and be paid monthly, I beg to say that the Department only requires returns to be prepared and forwarded at the end of each quarter. We cannot pay her for her services monthly, but an advance on her salary could be made about the middle of each quarter upon application by her forwarded through your office.

Your obedient servant,

A. F. MacKenzie,
Acting Asst. Deputy and Secretary.

R. H. Kennedy, Esq.,

Dear Sir,

With reference to your telegram of the 3rd instant, cheque #16752, for $65.00, in payment of Mr. McKinnon's salary for the month of September was forwarded to him at Truro, N. S., on the 25th ultimo. It should have reached him before this date. If he has not received it by the time this letter reaches you, he should make inquiries from the Post Office officials.

The cheques in payment of the salary of the teacher at this school will be forwarded at the end of each month. If he should give up duties at any time, you should immediately inform the Department in order that his name may be removed from the paylist.

A quarterly return should be prepared by the teacher at the end of September, December, March and June and forwarded to the Department through your office. Forms for this purpose are enclosed.

Dear Mr Hoey,

Replying to yours of the 18th ult., I want to thank you for the books which are very instructive, in an easy reading style. The science books are very good and are proving quite popular with the students. Concerning the manual to grant it is more than I hoped for and I expect to have it completed this week. I have a model of a hand sleigh which I hope to have all the boys complete long before spring. Several of the better wood workers of the reservation have promised to help out as I am not much good in that line. Thanks you sincerely.

I wonder Mr. Hoey about the cheque whether it comes usually at the end of December or the last teaching day. I certainly hope it will be here.
by the 22nd or I'll have to spend Xmas here. I wonder is it possible for me to get it a day or two before the 22nd as the Xmas enter tantment will cost me a few dollars over & above the departmental grant for gifts & candies for 21 children.

Could you advise me on that point?

Thank you again. I am

Yours Truly,

J.B. McKinnon

Dear Sir -

This is the 6th day July and my cheque has not yet arrived. As you will understand this has caused a great annoyance. It necessitates my staying in Truro paying over £1.25 per day board; it means that I lose employment awaiting me at home @ 2.50 per day.

So far this oversight or negligence has cost me at least 20s which to a person unemployed for 2 mos. and when employed will receive no remuneration until 30th Sept. is not quite fair. Even worse than that my credit at a local finance co. is endangered as my note was due the 2nd inst.

Please investigate at once and I think it is only fair to expect some remuneration to cover at least my board. Sincerely,

Dear Sir:

I regret to learn, from your letter of the 6th instant, that you have not yet received your salary cheque for the month of June. In this connection I may say that cheque No. 87765 for $75.00, in your favour, was mailed here on June 28th, last, and should have reached you by July first.

Please make further enquiries from the postal officials. I might add that we phoned the Finance Department this morning and the cheque has not yet been cashed.

Under separate cover, you will be forwarded Bond of Indemnity Form. If you do not locate the cheque by the time this form reaches you, please complete the form, have it signed by two sureties and return same to this Department, in order that a duplicate cheque may be issued. If, however, you locate the cheque, the form that is being sent you should be returned.

I regret very much the inconvenience that has been caused you, but you will see from this letter that it is due to circumstances beyond our control.

Yours truly,

Philip Phelan,
Chief, Training Division.

Sir:
The school building at this Reserve is in need of some repairs consisting of a new floor, and the walls replastered or sheathed. Also a few repairs on roof and floor porch. The costs will do for a few years with some minor repairs. I believe the walls would be better sheathed than replastered, and probably the cost of sheathing will be less.

I beg to submit two tenders for this work: Halliday Galtman $160 and James H. Kenney $155. Steven Eldridge of this Reserve says he will do this work for $130, and will employ all Indian labor. Eldridge is a handy man, and quite capable of doing a satisfactory job. I think the tender of $130.00 is reasonable for this work, and if it is your wish to have this work done, I beg to recommend that it be given to Steven Eldridge at the above figure.

Ottawa, August 24, 1935.

Sir:

I have your letter of the 17th instant, regarding the repairs required to the Millbrook Indian Day School building and enclosing quotations which you received for the work.

In reply I have to say that you may arrange with Steven Gleade to carry out the repairs, consisting of installing a new floor, sheeting the walls, making the repairs required to the roof and floor of porch and any minor repairs necessary to the seats. Gleade should employ Indian labour, as far as possible.

I would request that you arrange to have the repairs completed at an early date. You should see that a satisfactory job is completed and the cost should not exceed the quotation of Gleade for this work, viz.: $130. This is to cover the cost of materials and labour. It may be that the work will not be completed in time for the school to re-open on September third, next, but it is hoped that there will be no unnecessary delay.

After the work has been completed to your satisfaction, you should obtain accounts, in triplicate, stating in detail the work carried out. These accounts, you should attach to proper voucher forms, certify in the usual manner and forward for payment. It is hoped that, when the work is completed, the school building will be in a good state of repair.

Your obedient servant,

A. F. MacNeece,
Secretary.

MILLBROOK SCHOOL:

This school is of frame construction covered with shingles the whole of which is white-washed or painted white. The interior of the school is a disgrace to the Department. The plaster is off the walls and ceiling in many places. The floor is nearly worn through and the whole building shakes when one walks around. This is probably due to the rotting away of the sills. The porch has two holes where the windows should be and the floor is rotted through. There is no means of locking the porch or outer door. The porch roof leaks and the woodshed door is open allowing the Indians to remove wood at will. The stove is 35 years old and is held together by rods. The seats are in bad condition, being very rickety. I instructed the Indian Agent to buy a cheap padlock for the shed and report fully on the condition of this building to the Department.

Dr. McGill

OTTAWA.

Dear Sir:-

I find at Truro quite a number of the Indians make fancy baskets and ax handles which they have to sell wholesale at ridiculous low prices. As the Trans Canada Highway runs through this reserve there must be a great many tourists pass over this road.

It appears to me that if there was a wigwam or some such structure erected there might be with two or three nice signs that they might be able to dispose of quite a lot of their work at fair prices.

I think the Indians would do the work at very little expense to the Dept.

Will you please give me your opinion on this matter and if agreeable what amount the Dept. would be willing to contribute.

Re the ax handles, there must be a great number of those used by our Natl. Parks, etc., could not some arrangements be made to take those made by the Indians. They claim they are much superior to the factory made ones.

The school grounds at Truro are in bad shape would it not be a good idea to require any Indians who are able to work and require relief to work on these grounds. Discontinue direct relief. Require them to do road work, repairs to buildings etc in exchange for any future relief.

Yours very truly,

Thos. Robertson.

Dear Sir:

The attention of the Department has been called to the need of repairs to the building and the filling and levelling of the grounds at the Millbrook Indian Day School. It has been suggested that some change be made in the lighting of the school building, as it does not seem to be satisfactory.

No doubt, you are aware that, last August, the Department incurred an expenditure of approximately $130 in repairs to the interior of the building. I would request that you furnish a report, at an early date, stating what further repairs are required to place this building in a good condition, giving an estimate of the cost for material and labour. Please report, also, regarding the condition of the grounds around the school, and, if you recommend that any work be undertaken in filling and levelling, you should furnish an estimate of the cost of the labour and any material that may be required.

When this information is received, the Department will give consideration as to whether any funds to carry out the work can be provided from the Appropriation for the current fiscal year.

Yours truly,

A. F. MacKenzie,
Secretary.

Sir:

Reporting on the repairs to building and filling, levelling of grounds, at the Millbrook Indian Day School, I wish to state:

1st:—Changing of windows to assure better lighting of school room and changing the seats, repairing broken ones, etc., can be done at an expenditure of not more than $50.00. Perhaps quite a bit less, all according to what we will meet in making the change.

There is a space in the floor that will require covering. For some reason or other the space under the teachers platform was not boarded over. This makes a cold draft for the teacher in winter. I know the department spent quite a substantial amount last year on this school, and it is regrettable that the changes we now recommend were not then made.

Several of the seats are in need of repairs, all of which can be done by Indians, with only a few dollars expended for material. Since I last wrote in connection with filling and levelling the grounds, I took advantage of highway work now going on to secure about fifty loads of surplus earth and gravel, the road builders had to give away. This was put on the School field and levelled off by the young men near by, at no cost to us.

An expenditure now of about $100 on the grounds, all of which will go to Indians, excepting perhaps some material for fencing, will give us a splendid school field, and will keep the kiddies from the highway, which now hard surfaced, will be a source of danger where there are no sidewalks.

The grounds are very wet and need draining as well as filling and levelling.

An expenditure of approximately $150.00 will give us the School accommodations required for many years. Doctors have recommended the suggested change to safeguard the sight and health of the children.

Your obedient servant,

A. F. MacKenzie,
Secretary,
Dept. of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa.

B. E. Exx.,
Indian Agent,
Truro, N. S.

Dear Sir:

I have your letter of the 30th ultimo, reporting on the repairs required to the school building and filling and levelling of the grounds at the Millbrook Indian Day School.

In reply I have to say that the Department will approve of you incurring an expenditure of approximately $150 in carrying out the following work at this school:

1. Changing of windows in order to obtain better lighting of classroom.
2. Changing seats and repairing any broken ones.
3. Boarding over the space under teacher's platform.
4. Levelling, filling, draining and fencing grounds.

You are to purchase any materials required, from firms on the approved list, and have all work, as far as possible, carried out by Indian labour. After the work has been completed, to your satisfaction, please obtain itemized accounts, in triplicate, covering the cost of all materials, and accounts, in triplicate, covering the amount due for the labour employed. The accounts for the labour should show the number of days or hours employed and the rate paid. These accounts, you should attach to proper voucher forms, certify in the usual manner and forward for payment. I would suggest that the work in changing the windows, repairing desks, etc., be carried out during the summer holidays. The sum mentioned should not be exceeded in connection with all the work at this school.

Yours truly,

B. B. Fox, Esq.,
Indian Agent,
Truro, N. S.

Besides the work that had been authorized before I arrived, I instructed the Agent to have one side of roof shingled, the porch at entrance moved and new steps build, also the repairing of shed and building of toilets. As this school is situated on the main highway, between Truro and Halifax, I authorized the painting of the school building - one coat, with two coats on front and roof stained. The total cost of all repairs would be approximately $250. All labour was performed by the Indians.

I also authorized the Agent to purchase four double desks.

The grounds at this school have been levelled and drained and are now in fairly good shape.

The windows in the classroom are all placed on one side of the building. The school building is built on a cement foundation and a flagpole was erected. The sign with the name of the school has been placed on the front of the building.

Since the repairs have been completed, the building presents a good appearance and is a credit to the Department.

Agent Fox takes a great interest in the school and also in improving the Indian homes on the reserve. Considerable work was done on the reserve in carrying out repairs during the past summer, all work being done by the Indians, themselves - the Department supplying the material.

Sir:

Mr. MacKinnon, our teacher, today made urgent petition for tooth brushes and dental cream for the pupils in Millbrook School. He tells me that this particular hygienic need has been sadly neglected among the children on the Reservation and as the consequence the teeth and mouth are in very bad state.

In conversing with the teacher I suggested that even if we gave the pupils brushes they would not take care of their teeth in the home as no doubt the parents are also negligent in this respect. He said that for a time he would keep the brushes in the school and each day give instructions to the kiddies on the care of their teeth. There are now twenty Indian children attending school and three more will be starting in a few days and there is only one child on the Reserve that has a tooth brush. We need therefore, two dozen brushes and a quantity of paste or powder from time to time.

Also, because of signs of tubercular trouble among several of the children Mr. MacKinnon also requested some kind of a closed receptacle or tank for water. I enquired at the hardware store here and find they have a properly constructed water tank with tap and the cost is $7.50.

INSTALL SEATS IN MILLBROOK INDIAN SCHOOL

TRURO, March 26 — Another step toward modernizing conditions on the Millbrook reservation is being made by the Department of Mines and Resources, Ottawa. The local agent received approval of his plan to change the school seating arrangements and installing the most modern equipment.

Yesterday a large order was placed with the Dominion Chair Company for new seats for the higher grades and the modern seating equipment for the kindergarten and primary classes. Meanwhile, already a library has been installed, the first ever to be placed in the Indian schools here.

Last year large sums were spent in improving the buildings and grounds of the school, and this year additional funds have been allotted for an outdoor basketball court and walks as well as more drainage for the school grounds. The school is under the supervision of the provincial school inspector and provides the Indian children there are a number of white children from the Halifax area who attend the school under a joint agreement with the town of Truro.

A report upon consideration and approaches may be made to the federal government by local school authorities to have the school enlarged to accommodate more children and in large way solve an urgent problem that now confronts the lower grades in the town schools.

Memorandum:

Dr. H.W. McGill.

While returning from Halifax last week I took the opportunity of dropping off at Truro between trains and visiting the band of Indians on the Millbrook Reserve.

I visited the school and had a talk with the teacher (Mr. McKinnon). I told Mr. McKinnon that I would pass this information along to you.

I then visited the Indian Agent, Mr. Fox, who showed me the supplies received from surplus belonging to the National Defence. These were in good condition and he was very much pleased with the same.

Mr. Fox stated that he thought considerable saving could be effected in the purchase of flour and drugs. He thought a half carload of flour might be purchased at once and stored by him for issue to the Indians, as required. With reference to medicines, he thought a saving might be effected by purchasing through the Department of National Health.

I am passing these suggestions along to you for your consideration.

Sir:

Sir:

In closely questioning the school pupils who were tubercular tested today I learned that the milk we are giving for these children is largely consumed by adults.

I would recommend and petition approval of the Department that the milk for the school children be delivered to the school and the children given a half a pint twice daily. Mr. McKinnon, the teacher assured me he would co-operate and distribute the milk as directed.

It will not materially increase the monthly milk bill. It means to stop the milk going to the home of each child and taken to the school.

We have quite a serious situation re T.B., among children but according to Dr. McRitchie proper action now will practically in all cases stop further inroads by the disease.

Sir:

After the closing of the School for the summer holidays I made a survey of needed improvements.

The nurse who accompanied Dr. McRitchie on the T. B. Test and also the Provincial School Inspectors have recommended a jacket around the stove in the school. This would cause the heat to rise and spread over the room rather than strike the kiddies direct as at present.

Also the stone drain which was placed from the school to the ditch on the highway has settled considerably and this causes water to lie in the hollow places during wet weather.

The desks need varnishing to protect the wood and the plank steps to the front entrance of the school building are badly rotted.

Following is an itemized statement of our requirements with prices that I have had quoted:

- Jacket for stove 3 x 5 x 3 ft. medium sheet iron with feet to screw to floor quotation from Dexter & Company $12.00
- 4 truck loads of gravel, 3 yards in each load, landed on school yard, quoted by Albert Beals at $15.00
- 500 square feet of plank quoted by Consolidated Lumber Company $21.00
- Varnish for the desks about one gallon estimated at $3.50
- Labor on the entire work estimated at $20.00.

The planks mentioned are to be used to cover a ditch which would join to the school yard a small piece of land that was left when a curve on the highway was taken off a few years ago. The accompanying sketch may fully explain the grounds.

The total cost would be approximately $71.50.

Your obedient servant,
